inventory.summary: The Swedish Digitalisation Strategy 2025–2030 emphasizes enhancing digital inclusion, security, and sustainability. It aims to empower citizens through improved digital skills and services while ensuring robust data protection and infrastructure. The strategy outlines goals for digital transformation across sectors, focusing on societal benefit and economic competitiveness.

values.name: Human dignity
values.evidence: KI wird im Einklang mit den Grundrechten eingeführt und eingesetzt. Die Persönlichkeitsrechte von Mitarbeitenden sowie Bürgerinnen und Bürgern, insbesondere das Recht auf informationelle Selbstbestimmung, sind dabei zu achten.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Der Einsatz von KI selbst soll fair und diskriminierungsfrei gestaltet sein.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: Es sollten vor und während des Einsatzes von KI-Systemen geeignete Maßnahmen ergriffen werden, damit dieser nicht zu verzerrten Ergebnissen führt (Diskriminierungsfreiheit).

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Datenschutzkonformer KI-Einsatz.

values.name: Autonomy/self-determination
values.evidence: Unser Ziel ist es, mit dem KI-Einsatz menschliche Handlungsspielräume zu erweitern und nicht, diese zu reduzieren.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: KI soll Arbeitsprozesse verbessern oder erleichtern und den Nutzenden einen Mehrwert bieten.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Wir setzen auf vertrauenswürdige KI-Systeme.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Vertrauenswürdige KI erfüllt ihre Funktionen sicher und zuverlässig ('technisch robust') und ist resilient gegenüber externen Eingriffen.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Wir richten den Einsatz von KI vor diesem Hintergrund stets auf das Gemeinwohl aus (Menschenzentrierung).

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: Dabei wird größtmögliche ökologische, ökonomische, organisatorische, technische und soziale Nachhaltigkeit bei der Entwicklung und dem Einsatz von KI angestrebt.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Zudem sollten sie in diesen Fällen möglichst nachvollziehen können, anhand welcher Maßstäbe und auf Basis welcher Informationen die KI Ergebnisse erzielt.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Im Einklang mit gesetzlichen Rahmenbedingungen muss es beim Einsatz von KI klare Verantwortlichkeiten geben.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Der KI-Einsatz erfolgt unter angemessener menschlicher Aufsicht.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Soweit möglich sollten alle Mitarbeitenden die gleichen Chancen auf Zugang bekommen.

principles.name: Robustness/reliability
principles.evidence: Vertrauenswürdige KI erfüllt ihre Funktionen sicher und zuverlässig ('technisch robust').

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Je höher das Risiko, welches mit dem Einsatz von KI verbunden ist, desto mehr rücken menschliche Aufsicht und Kontrolle in den Vordergrund (risikobasierter Ansatz).

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: KI-Systeme sollten beispielsweise dem Einsatzzweck entsprechend auf geeigneten und repräsentativen Trainingsdaten basieren.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: Die Persönlichkeitsrechte von Mitarbeitenden sowie Bürgerinnen und Bürgern, insbesondere das Recht auf informationelle Selbstbestimmung, sind dabei zu achten.

principles.name: Purpose limitation
principles.evidence: Die Bundesverwaltung setzt KI chancenorientiert dort ein, wo diese einen Mehrwert im Sinne der dienstlichen Aufgabenerfüllung schafft.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Zudem sollte die allgemeine ethische Wertegrundlage bei der Verwendung von KI angemessen berücksichtigt werden.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: KI-Systeme werden vor ihrem Einsatz sowie fortlaufend in verschiedenen Situationen und Umgebungen durch die verantwortliche Behörde auf ihre Widerstandsfähigkeit getestet.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Reallabore als geeignete Räume zur Unterstützung einer solchen Einzelfallprüfung dienen.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Die vorliegenden KI-Leitlinien werden dabei durch geltende Standards sowie fachspezifische Vorgaben und Veröffentlichungen ergänzt.

mechanisms.name: Ethics board/committee
mechanisms.evidence: Die Gleichstellungsbeauftragten und die gewählten Interessenvertretungen der Mitarbeitenden sowie die für den Datenschutz zuständigen Stellen in den Ressorts sind frühzeitig einzubeziehen.

inventory.summary: The AI Guidelines for Germany's federal administration emphasize a values-based approach to AI deployment, focusing on human dignity, fairness, and sustainability. They establish principles such as transparency, accountability, and human oversight, while proposing mechanisms like training and regulatory sandboxes to ensure responsible AI use. The guidelines align with the EU AI Act and aim to balance innovation with ethical considerations, prioritizing public interest and trust.

title: Mandatory Guardrails for Safe and Responsible AI

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: The potential for Artificial Intelligence (AI) to improve social and economic well-being is immense.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: A commitment was made to develop a regulatory environment that builds community trust and promotes AI adoption.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: The community expects governments to safeguard the safety and security of AI systems.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Our purpose is to help the government build a better future for all Australians.

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: A productive, resilient and sustainable economy, enriched by science and technology.

values.name: Cultural diversity
values.evidence: Reinforces opportunities for Australia to be a leading international voice on regulatory approaches for AI that address sustainability, Indigenous Cultural and Intellectual Property (ICIP), Caring for Country and First Nations values.

values.name: Democracy
values.evidence: Council of Europe adopting the Framework Convention on Artificial Intelligence and Human Rights, Democracy and the Rule of Law.

values.name: Rule of law
values.evidence: Council of Europe adopting the Framework Convention on Artificial Intelligence and Human Rights, Democracy and the Rule of Law.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency about how AI products are developed and used with end-users, other actors in the AI supply chain and relevant authorities.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Accountability for governing and managing the risks associated with AI systems.

principles.name: Risk-based approach
principles.evidence: A risk-based approach has been developed, with emphasis on measures including testing, transparency and accountability.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Supporting AI capability, including through existing programs like the AI Adopt Program and investments through the National Reconstruction Fund.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: We engage internationally to share our regulatory approaches and best-practice policies.

principles.name: Multi-stakeholder governance
principles.evidence: Active engagement and feedback is sought on the issues above from a broad cross-section of industry, civil society, academia, workers and the community.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: Public trust in AI remains low, which is slowing adoption by businesses and organisations.

principles.name: Purpose limitation
principles.evidence: Defining high-risk AI – the proposed principles for determining high-risk AI settings and their potential application to general-purpose AI (GPAI) models.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: The Australian Government is operationalising Australia’s AI Ethics Principles across all its AI policy initiatives.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Testing during development and in deployment to ensure systems perform as intended and meet appropriate performance metrics.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The proposed mandatory guardrails outlined in this paper sit alongside other initiatives, including the development of a Voluntary AI Safety Standard.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The government is developing a Voluntary AI Safety Standard for organisations using AI to provide organisation-level and system-level best practice for developers and deployers.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The DTA will also soon pilot a draft Commonwealth AI Assurance Framework to support a more consistent approach by agencies to assessing and mitigating the risks of AI use.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Options include adapting existing regulatory frameworks to introduce additional guardrails on AI, or creating new frameworks such as through framework legislation or by introducing an Australian AI Act.

mechanisms.name: Sectoral regulation
mechanisms.evidence: The Australian Government announced an investment of $4.2 million in the 2024–25 Budget to clarify and strengthen existing laws impacted by AI, with reviews in priority areas of health care, consumer and copyright law.

mechanisms.name: Code of conduct/voluntary commitments
mechanisms.evidence: Implementing the Voluntary AI Safety Standard now will help businesses start to develop practices required in a future regulatory environment.

referenced_frameworks: Council of Europe Framework Convention on Artificial Intelligence and Human Rights, Democracy and the Rule of Law
Hiroshima AI Process Code of Conduct
inventory.summary: The policy document outlines Australia's approach to AI governance, emphasizing mandatory guardrails for high-risk AI settings. It prioritizes values such as well-being, trust, and safety, and principles like transparency and accountability. The policy proposes mechanisms like impact assessments and standards to ensure responsible AI development and deployment, aligning with international frameworks and promoting public trust and innovation.

title: The Rules Governing the National Register of Controllers Within the Kingdom

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The purpose of these Rules is to inform and monitor Controllers within the Kingdom of the scope of their obligation to register on the National Data Governance Platform... providing services related to the protection of personal data.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: This measure is taken to protect personal data and enhance confidence in the services provided.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The Platform offers a range of e-services aimed at protecting data as national assets and safeguarding the rights of individuals from illegal violations.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The representative must complete the registration process on the Platform... and determine the need to appoint a Personal Data Protection Officer.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The Competent Authority allows the public to verify the registration of Controllers in the national registry by reviewing the registration certificate and verifying its authenticity.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Update the controller’s data on regular basis to ensure it is up-to-date.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: The Controller shall appoint one or more individuals to be responsible for the protection of personal data.

mechanisms.name: Registration/inventory of AI systems
mechanisms.evidence: These Rules shall be applicable to Controllers... mandated to register on the Platform.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Privacy Impact Assessment Service: This tool analyzes the impact of processing personal data on the products and services provided.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Compliance Assessment Service: This service involves periodically evaluating compliance with specific standards and requirements.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Personal Data Breach Notification Service: This service enables Controllers to notify a personal data breach incident to the Competent Authority immediately after its occurrence.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Legal Support Service: This service provides support and guidance to assist public entities in understanding the Personal Data Protection Law and its regulations.

inventory.summary: The policy establishes a National Register of Controllers to ensure compliance with personal data protection laws in Saudi Arabia. It emphasizes privacy and data protection, requiring entities to register and appoint data protection officers. The policy includes mechanisms for impact assessment, compliance monitoring, and public transparency to enhance trust and safeguard individual rights.

values.name: Trust

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building

inventory.summary: The AI Adoption Framework by Saudi Arabia emphasizes responsible and secure AI use aligned with national priorities. It highlights privacy, trust, and fairness as core values, and proposes mechanisms like impact assessments and capacity building to ensure ethical AI integration. The framework aims to balance innovation with societal protection, fostering public trust and aligning with Saudi Vision 2030.

title: Standard Contractual Clauses for Personal Data Transfer

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The purpose of these Clauses is to ensure the application of a level of protection of Personal Data equivalent to the level of protection applied under the Law and Regulations.

values.name: Accountability
values.evidence: Each party shall be accountable to the other party for any damages caused to the other party as a result of a breach of any of these Standard Contractual Clauses.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The Personal Data Importer must agree to respond to the Competent Authority's requests and cooperate with its auditing procedures and approved compliance follow-up measures.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: All parties shall take the necessary organizational, administrative, and technical measures that ensure to maintain the privacy of personal Data against any breach at all stages of processing.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The parties shall provide a copy of these Clauses to the Competent Authority upon request and without undue delay.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Each party shall be accountable to the other party for any damages caused to the other party as a result of a breach of any of these Standard Contractual Clauses.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: The Personal Data Importer must agree to respond to the Competent Authority's requests and cooperate with its auditing procedures and approved compliance follow-up measures.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The Personal Data Importer shall retain the transferred Personal Data if it is necessary to fulfill the purposes set out in Appendix (2).

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: The Personal Data Exporter shall assist the Personal Data Importer in fulfilling the necessary data security requirements.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: The Personal Data Importer must notify the competent authority within (72) hours of becoming aware of the incident, in accordance with the requirements stated in Article (24) of the Implementing Regulations of the Law.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: The Personal Data Importer agrees and commits to cooperate with the Competent Authority and comply with all its requests and inquiries and provide the necessary documents and information to ensure compliance with the Standard Contractual Clauses.

mechanisms.name: Penalties/sanctions/enforcement
mechanisms.evidence: The Personal Data Subject has the right to claim before the competent court for compensation for material or moral damage in proportion to the magnitude of the damage arising from the application of these Standard Contractual Clauses.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The Personal Data Exporter shall assist the Personal Data Importer in fulfilling the necessary data security requirements.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: The Personal Data Subject may submit to the Competent Authority any complaint arising from the application of the provisions of these Standard Contractual Clauses.

inventory.summary: The policy establishes Standard Contractual Clauses to ensure the protection of personal data transferred outside Saudi Arabia, aligning with the Personal Data Protection Law. It emphasizes privacy, accountability, and security, requiring parties to adhere to transparency and data governance principles. Mechanisms include mandatory impact assessments, audits, and redress mechanisms to enforce compliance and protect data subjects' rights.

title: National AI Strategy of the Czech Republic 2030

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: The goal of this strategy...is to use the maximum potential of artificial intelligence for the benefit of the Czech economy and society.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Ethical and legal aspects of AI are crucial to building the public trust and protecting the rights of individuals.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: The goal of the strategy is therefore to ensure the security of AI systems and strengthen the resistance to cyber attacks.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The benefits of AI are used to the benefit of society as a whole.

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: Ethical and legal aspects of AI are crucial to...protecting the rights of individuals.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: These measures will lead to...a greater trust of citizens thanks to the transparent and ethical use of AI.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Establish supervisory bodies and promote the ethical use of AI.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: The involvement of Czech scientists in international projects and the exchange of knowledge between the academia and industry.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Prevent digital exclusion and increase citizens' information literacy.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The goal is to ensure quality data, a modern digital infrastructure...

mechanisms.name: Ethics board/committee
mechanisms.evidence: Establish supervisory bodies and promote the ethical use of AI.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Measures include...teacher training, expansion of study programs in the field of AI and awareness campaigns.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Creation of a regulatory sandbox for testing AI innovations.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Regularly monitor and prevent threats, and work closely with renowned international partners.

mechanisms.name: Code of conduct/voluntary commitments
mechanisms.evidence: Create codes of ethics for developers and users.

inventory.summary: The National AI Strategy of the Czech Republic 2030 emphasizes the ethical use of AI to benefit society and the economy, focusing on well-being, trust, and security. It proposes mechanisms like ethics boards and regulatory sandboxes, and highlights principles such as transparency and international cooperation to ensure responsible AI development and deployment.

title: Guidelines for the use of generative AI in the public administration

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The guidelines shall be based on current regulations and be based on the state's core values in order to create trust, transparency and build trust.

values.name: Transparency
values.evidence: The guidelines shall be based on current regulations and be based on the state's core values in order to create trust, transparency and build trust.

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: The guidelines shall serve as guidance and support for the use of generative AI for employees of state authorities, municipalities and regions from a legal, security and ethical perspective.

values.name: Public interest/Common good
values.evidence: The guidelines will also support public administration in taking advantage of generative AI in a way that fosters innovation and development.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The guidelines shall be based on current regulations and be based on the state's core values in order to create trust, transparency and build trust.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The guidelines will serve as a guide and support in the use of generative AI for employees at government agencies, municipalities and regions from legal, security and ethical perspectives.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: DIGG will offer competence-enhancing initiatives to smaller actors in public administration in order to promote the administration's appropriate and efficient use of AI.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: The authorities must therefore conduct a dialogue with the relevant public and private actors during the implementation of the assignment.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: DIGG will offer competence-enhancing initiatives to smaller actors in public administration in order to promote the administration's appropriate and efficient use of AI.

mechanisms.name: Standards/Technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The guidelines will make use of already existing knowledge support, e.g. The trust model for AI managed by DIGG.

mechanisms.name: Other: Methodological support
mechanisms.evidence: The guidelines will serve as methodological support and provide guidance for the activities' assessments of whether and how generative AI should be used.

inventory.summary: The policy provides guidelines for the ethical, safe, and effective use of generative AI in Sweden's public administration. It emphasizes trust, transparency, and security, while proposing mechanisms like training and methodological support to enhance AI use. The guidelines aim to foster innovation and development while ensuring accountability and inclusiveness.

inventory.summary: The European Digital Innovation Hubs (EDIHs) policy focuses on enhancing digital competitiveness and sustainability through a network of hubs providing technical expertise, training, and innovation services. It emphasizes international cooperation and inclusiveness, with mechanisms for capacity building and performance evaluation. The policy implicitly supports public interest and trust in AI solutions.

inventory.summary: The Veritas Initiative is a multi-phased project under Singapore's National AI Strategy, focusing on the financial sector. values.evidence: Consider the right to respect for a private and family life enshrined in Article 8 of the Human Rights Act 1998.

principles.evidence: What about accountability?

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Select the least intrusive means to achieve it.

principles.name: Human Oversight/Human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: What is the role of human oversight?

principles.name: Data Governance/Data Quality
principles.evidence: What about accuracy?

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: This guidance is aimed at all organisations, both public and private sector.

principles.name: Precaution/Risk-based Approach
principles.evidence: Carrying out a data protection impact assessment (DPIA) may also help in identifying the most appropriate basis.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & Evaluation/Reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Regularly review the information you are collecting and destroy what is not necessary.

mechanisms.name: Code of Conduct/Voluntary Commitments
mechanisms.evidence: Employers should keep this under review. Where a DPIA is not mandatory, employers should consider completing one anyway for good practice.

inventory.summary: The policy provides guidance on lawful and fair monitoring of workers, emphasizing data protection, transparency, and accountability. title: Approach Document for India: Part 2 - Operationalizing Principles for Responsible AI

values.name: Human dignity
values.evidence: AI should promote positive human values and not disturb social harmony.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: AI systems must treat individuals under the same circumstances equally.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: AI should not deepen harmful historic and social divisions based on religion, race, caste, sex.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: AI should maintain privacy and security of data with sufficient safeguards.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: AI should be deployed reliably with sufficient safeguards to ensure safety.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Lack of trust in technology and AI systems has inhibited their adoption.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The goal must be to maximize the benefits of AI for citizens, businesses, and research.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The design and functioning of the AI system should be recorded and made available for external scrutiny.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: All stakeholders involved in the design, development, and deployment of the AI system must be responsible for their actions.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: AI should not deny opportunity to a qualified person on the basis of their identity.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Regulation must be proportional to the likelihood of harm that can be occasioned by an AI system.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Ensuring that AI systems adhere to the principles requires a multi-disciplinary approach.

inventory.summary: The 'Automated Vehicles' Bill in Germany's Road Traffic Act establishes a regulatory framework for the operation of vehicles with automated and autonomous driving functions. It emphasizes safety, non-maleficence, and privacy, requiring human oversight and accountability. The policy mandates certification, data governance, and training to ensure compliance with technical standards and public safety.

inventory.summary: The Diia AI Assistant policy emphasizes privacy and data protection as its primary ethical values, ensuring user data is encrypted and anonymized. It operates under principles of transparency and accountability, with mechanisms for user consent and feedback to improve service quality. The policy aims to enhance public trust and serve the common good by providing secure and accessible government services.

title: ASEAN Guide on AI Governance and Ethics

values.name: Fairness/Justice/Equity
values.evidence: Deployers should have safeguards in place to ensure that algorithmic decisions do not further exacerbate or amplify existing discriminatory or unjust impacts.

values.name: Privacy/Data Protection
values.evidence: AI systems should have proper mechanisms in place to ensure data privacy and protection.

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: AI systems should be safe and sufficiently secure against malicious attacks.

values.name: Human-centricity
values.evidence: AI systems should respect human-centred values and pursue benefits for human society.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The seven guiding principles below help to ensure trust in AI and the design, development, and deployment of ethical AI systems.

values.name: Public Interest/Common Good
values.evidence: AI systems should be used to promote human well-being and ensure benefit for all.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency refers to providing disclosure on when an AI system is being used and the involvement of an AI system in decision-making.

principles.name: Explainability/Interpretability
principles.evidence: Explainability is the ability to communicate the reasoning behind an AI system’s decision in a way that is understandable.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Deployers have a responsibility to clearly disclose the implementation of an AI system to stakeholders.

principles.name: Robustness/Reliability
principles.evidence: Ensuring traceability by building an audit trail to document the AI system development and decision-making process.

principles.name: Human Oversight/Human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Three broad categories of human involvement based on level of risk – human-in-the-loop, human-over-the-loop, human-out-of-the-loop.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: AI systems should not result in unfair biasness or discrimination.

principles.name: Data Governance/Data Quality
principles.evidence: Data protocols need to be set up to govern who can access data and when data can be accessed.

principles.name: Precaution/Risk-based Approach
principles.evidence: Conduct risk-based assessments before starting any data collection and processing or modelling.

mechanisms.name: Ethics board/committee
mechanisms.evidence: Multi-disciplinary, central governing body, such as an AI Ethics Advisory Board, to oversee AI governance efforts.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Conduct relevant risk impact assessments to determine level of risk.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Facilitating auditability by keeping a comprehensive record of data provenance, procurement, pre-processing, lineage, storage, and security.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Nurturing AI talent and upskilling workforce.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Updates to this Guide may be published subsequently to keep up with evolutions and growth in governance and standards.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Develop standards, guidelines, tools, and templates to help organisations design, develop, and deploy AI responsibly.

referenced_frameworks: EU Ethics Guidelines for Trustworthy AI
inventory.summary: The ASEAN Guide on AI Governance and Ethics provides a comprehensive framework for the responsible design, development, and deployment of AI systems in the region. It emphasizes transparency, fairness, safety, and human-centricity, proposing mechanisms such as ethics boards and impact assessments to ensure ethical AI practices. The guide aligns with international standards and encourages regional cooperation to foster trust and interoperability in AI governance.

title: Elaboration and Developing Privacy Policy Guideline

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Protecting Data Subjects' privacy.

values.name: Autonomy/self-determination
values.evidence: Helping Data Subjects to exercise their rights stipulated in the Law.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Ensuring compliance with the 'Right to Be Informed'.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Protect Personal Data from incidents of leakage, damage, or illegal access.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Achieving public interest by collecting and processing Personal Data.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The Controller shall provide access to the Privacy Policy and ensure that its content is written in clear, non-misleading, easy-to-read, and understandable language.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The Controller shall clarify the rights of Data Subjects regarding the collection and processing of their data.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: The Controller shall provide a mechanism for filing complaints and objections.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The Controller shall clarify Personal Data to be collected either before or during the collection process.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: Consent of Data Subject or his legal guardian; realized interest of Data Subject or legal requirement.

principles.name: Purpose limitation
principles.evidence: The purpose of collecting Personal Data shall be related directly to the Controller's activity.

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Content of Personal Data collected and processed shall be limited to the minimum necessary.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall provide a mechanism for filing complaints and objections.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall clarify whether Personal Data or a specific group thereof shall be disclosed to other entities.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Encouraging entities to adopt best practices, ensuring Personal Data privacy and protection.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall periodically review the Privacy Policy and record any amendment or update.

mechanisms.name: Registration/inventory of AI systems
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall write its official name in accordance with regulatory registers and trademarks.

title: Digital for Care: Digital Health Framework 2024-2030

values.name: Human dignity
values.evidence: Empowering patients by giving them access to their own health information.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Digital health has the potential to support equitable and universal access to quality health and social care services.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Transparency is the key to building trust so we will continue to engage patient representatives throughout the design and delivery of all digital health programmes.

values.name: Autonomy/self-determination
values.evidence: We will empower patients by giving them broader access to their own health information.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: Improved health and wellbeing for everyone.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Trust in Digital Health: high levels of trust in the security and confidentiality of the systems used by the health services.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Seamless, safe, secure, and connected digital health services.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Digital health solutions can help avoid admissions, reduce lengths of stay, improve the quality of care.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency is the key to building trust so we will continue to engage patient representatives.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Governance and oversight arrangements will need to be commensurate with the level of investment committed.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Patients are empowered to make shared decisions with healthcare professionals.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: We must ensure our health and social care services are digitally inclusive for all our population including vulnerable groups.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: We will leverage data analytics, business intelligence, visualisation, dashboards, and other digitally enabled management tools.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: My Consent: control over my health information and the kind of information I want to share.

principles.name: Purpose limitation
principles.evidence: The need to provide the necessary assurances on how data is processed, who has access to it and for what purpose.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: We must support staff through access to training initiatives that improve digital literacy.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Governance and oversight arrangements will need to be commensurate with the level of investment committed.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Develop and implement standards to connect our systems and health information.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Patients can express their preferences around consent, and how we ensure compliance under data privacy legislation.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: Data liquidity presents an opportunity to seamlessly and securely exchange data across diverse platforms.

It proposes mechanisms like training and standards to support a secure, inclusive, and efficient digital health ecosystem in Ireland.

inventory.summary: The National Alliance of Artificial Intelligence in Mexico aims to promote the ethical use of AI for the common good, emphasizing human rights, sustainability, democracy, and inclusion. It proposes mechanisms such as regulatory sandboxes and international cooperation to ensure transparency, accountability, and inclusiveness in AI governance.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The success of the Plan will be highly dependent on the capacity of public bodies to secure resources and tools that will enable them to respond adequately to the needs of their stakeholders at scale, and with pace, while retaining quality and trust in the delivery of public services.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Government recognises these technological developments for their enormous potential to speed up progress towards the attainment of Sustainable Development Goals (SGDs) and the Eighth National Development Plan (8NDP) objectives.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: The Plan outlines strategies for improving the National Cyber Security Index (NCSI).

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Government recognises that digital platforms provide new channels for service delivery, public engagement, and feedback, and increase efficiency.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Government has been collaborating with stakeholders, in exploring avenues for adopting alternative technologies such as satellite, v-sat and spectrum as tools to bridge the digital divide in the urban and the rural areas.

principles.name: Interoperability
principles.evidence: The Plan draws from the successes of previous initiatives by increasing ICT connectivity infrastructure and enhancing the integration of systems and services in the Public Service.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Government has continued investing in public sector digital platforms driven by the desire to achieve greater efficiency, transparency, and accountability.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The deployment of cloud services at the Tier 3 National Data Centre will enable Government institutions to host various services in accordance with data protection laws.

principles.name: Multi-stakeholder governance
principles.evidence: The NeGP is a framework for attaining the integration phase of the e-Government Master Plan 2030. This National Electronic Government Plan has been formulated through a multi-stakeholder process.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: The Government Digital Innovation Regulatory Sandbox is part of the National Electronic Government Plan.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The Plan outlines strategies for improving the National Cyber Security Index (NCSI), e-Government Development Index (EGDI) and Open Government Data Index (OGDI).

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Investment in digital skills and change management will enhance national technical capacities and competencies, and increased consumption of e-Government services.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The Plan outlines seven (7) e-Government strategic focus areas namely: Government digital infrastructure; platforms and services; digital skills and change management; innovation and entrepreneurship; information security; standards and compliance; as well as policy and regulatory frameworks.

inventory.summary: The National Electronic Government Plan of Zambia emphasizes digital transformation to enhance public service delivery, focusing on trust, public interest, and security. It promotes principles of transparency, inclusiveness, interoperability, and accountability, with mechanisms like regulatory sandboxes and capacity building to support implementation.

It advocates for inclusiveness, trust, and international cooperation, proposing mechanisms like a task force and data sharing to ensure responsible AI use.

title: National Framework for Artificial Intelligence in Digital Learning (AIDL)

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Promote AI use that is free from bias, discrimination, and unfair treatment, ensuring equal opportunities for all learners.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: AI Bias Detection and Mitigation... ensuring fairness and equitable access to educational opportunities for all learners.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Ensure that AI policies and practices adhere to all applicable data privacy regulations.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The NeLC aims to enhance trust in online learning.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Implement a comprehensive framework with specific indicators for identifying, assessing, and mitigating potential risks associated with AI implementation.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The Framework aims to help education policy makers... to enable a successful planning, developing and implementing of AI in digital learning.

values.name: Cultural diversity
values.evidence: Leverage GenAI to produce learning environments that are culturally adapted to learners.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Responsibility in leadership: Cultivate a culture that ensures responsibility and transparency in AI development, deployment, and decision-making.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Establish clear processes for identifying, addressing, and assigning responsibility for AI-related issues.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Maintain the role of educators in directing and overseeing the use of AI in classrooms.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: AI Bias Detection and Mitigation... ensuring fairness and equitable access to educational opportunities for all learners.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Diversity and Inclusion in Data Sets: The practice of ensuring that AI algorithms are trained on diverse and representative data sets.

principles.name: Due diligence
principles.evidence: Regularly review and update AI policies to reflect evolving technological advancements and ethical considerations.

principles.name: Other: Adaptability and agility
principles.evidence: Establish mechanisms for strategy and policy to remain agile and responsive to emerging technologies and methodologies.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Bias Audits: Thorough examinations of AI tools and systems to identify potential biases.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Teachers/faculty training needs for AI will also need to be identified and planned for.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Regular Technology Review: Continuous evaluation and updating of AI tools and technologies used in learning.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: It encompasses a suite of guidelines that includes protocols, standards, and practices.

mechanisms.name: Other: Governance structure
mechanisms.evidence: Define clear roles, responsibilities, and decision-making processes for AI implementation.

referenced_frameworks: UNESCO’s guidelines on AI use in education

values.name: Privacy/Data Protection
values.evidence: Employers engaged in electronic monitoring; prior notice required.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Employers must give prior written notice upon hiring to all employees who are subject to electronic monitoring.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The attorney general may enforce the provisions of this section.

mechanisms.name: Penalties/Sanctions/Enforcement
mechanisms.evidence: Any employer found to be in violation of this section shall be subject to a maximum civil penalty.

mechanisms.name: Labelling/Disclosure Requirements
mechanisms.evidence: Employers must post the notice of electronic monitoring in a conspicuous place.

inventory.summary: The New York Electronic Monitoring Bill mandates that employers provide prior written notice to employees subject to electronic monitoring, ensuring transparency and accountability. It enforces privacy protection through required disclosures and imposes penalties for non-compliance, with enforcement overseen by the attorney general.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Our vision for NAIS 2.0 is to achieve AI for the Public Good, for Singapore and the World.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: We will ensure that Singapore hosts the necessary infrastructure and provides a trusted environment for AI innovation.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: There are growing concerns over the safety and security risks of AI, particularly Generative AI models.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: AI can be a potent force for good, to uplift human potential.

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: Address the needs and challenges of our time. For example, in areas of global importance such as population health and climate change.

values.name: Economic growth
values.evidence: Unlock the next frontier of economic growth. We must master AI to overcome our labour and productivity challenges.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Address risks from the potential abuse and mismanagement of AI.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The current inscrutability of large language models (LLMs), which calls into question the validity, credibility, and legality of their output.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: We shall uplift and empower our people and businesses, equipping them with the capabilities and resources to thrive in an AI-enabled future.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: We advocate for the responsible and ethical use of AI. We are active participants in multi-stakeholder platforms such as the Global Partnership on AI (GPAI).

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: We will develop and roll out targeted courses to impart AI skills, for different public sector workforce segments.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: We must harness AI in a sustainable way to create positive impact – for new opportunities, better jobs, and safer, more meaningful connections.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: By working with the best-in-class to provide an innovation sandbox for AI development.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: We will develop and roll out targeted courses to impart AI skills, for different public sector workforce segments.

mechanisms.name: International cooperation
mechanisms.evidence: We are active participants in multi-stakeholder platforms such as the Global Partnership on AI (GPAI).

mechanisms.name: Open source/openness
mechanisms.evidence: We also launched AI Verify, an AI governance testing framework and software toolkit, and made it open source for developers.

mechanisms.name: Sectoral regulation
mechanisms.evidence: We will adopt a sector-specific, use case-centric approach, and we will focus our initial efforts on Leading Economic Sectors.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: We will continually review these Actions to respond to fast-moving developments in AI, across domains.

title: Guidance on Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) technologies based Medical Devices

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: The implementation of new technologies such as AI and ML may present risks that could jeopardize patient health and safety.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Undermine trust in healthcare, and adversely impact the management of healthcare.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: The purpose of improving patients care.

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: Manufacturers are required to demonstrate that their medical devices do not pose unacceptable risks.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The intended use of AI and ML technologies will determine whether they will be regulated as a medical device.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Manufacturers are required to demonstrate that their medical devices do not pose unacceptable risks.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Manufacturers should provide assurance that metrics of effectiveness and safety include outcomes that are meaningful to patients.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Evaluation of model performance in efficacy/effectiveness studies requires comparisons of clinicians’ performance with and without the AI/ML-based medical device.

principles.name: Risk-based approach
principles.evidence: The level of evaluation and independent review should be proportionate with the risk posed by the AI/ML-based medical device.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Risk controls for data collected by MD-based medical devices should include process activities through the data lifecycle.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: The reference dataset should meet the following requirements unless there is sufficient evidence to show that a requirement does not need to be met.

principles.name: Precaution
principles.evidence: The manufacturer should generate evidence on device performance that can be generalized to the entire intended population.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Manufacturers are required to demonstrate that their medical devices do not pose unacceptable risks.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Certain AI/ML-based medical devices may require independent review of the results of the clinical evaluation.

mechanisms.name: Certification/conformity assessment
mechanisms.evidence: The manufacturer must demonstrate sufficient clinical and technical equivalence of the other device.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Post market surveillance including monitoring, measurement and analysis of quality data.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Personnel who are assigned to AI/ML projects should be competent in performing their jobs.

mechanisms.name: Risk classification/tiered regulation
mechanisms.evidence: Medical devices are classified based on their intended use and degree of potential risk to human body.

mechanisms.name: Quality Management Systems
mechanisms.evidence: The AI/ML device shall be designed and manufactured, and monitored in accordance with Medical Devices Quality Management System (ISO 13485).

inventory.summary: The policy provides comprehensive guidance on the regulation of AI and ML-based medical devices in Saudi Arabia, emphasizing safety, accountability, and risk management. It mandates rigorous evaluation and monitoring processes, including clinical validation and post-market surveillance, to ensure these technologies do not pose unacceptable risks and contribute positively to patient care.

The policy aims to balance employee privacy with organizational accountability and security.

title: Finland AI Enforcement and Case Law in Employment

values.name: Good governance

values.name: Legal protection

values.name: Transparency

values.name: Transparency
values.evidence: An individual shall have the right to access information related to the activities of public entities to enhance the system of integrity, transparency, and accountability.

values.name: Non-discrimination

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: An individual shall have the right to access information related to the activities of public entities to enhance the system of integrity, transparency, and accountability.

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Any restrictions on requesting access to or obtainment of protected information received, produced, or managed by public entities shall be justified in a clear and explicit manner.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Every individual shall be entitled to access or obtain (unprotected) public information; such Requestor shall not necessarily have a certain status or interest in this information to be able to obtain same.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: A public entity shall be responsible for preparing and implementing policies and procedures related to exercising the right to access or obtain public information.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building

mechanisms.name: Open source/openness

inventory.summary: The Freedom of Information Policy in Saudi Arabia emphasizes transparency, non-discrimination, and public interest by ensuring individuals' rights to access public information. It mandates public entities to establish mechanisms for accountability, monitoring, and redress, while promoting open data initiatives to support economic growth and innovation.

values.name: Privacy/data protection

values.name: Public interest/common good

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Data shall be classified into levels based on its nature, sensitivity and impact, taking into consideration balancing its value against its confidentiality level.

principles.name: Need to Know
principles.evidence: Data access and use shall be made pursuant to the Need-to-Know principle and for the least possible number of people.

principles.name: Least Privilege
principles.evidence: The privileges of personnel members shall be limited to minimal access required to perform the tasks and responsibilities assigned to them.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Open by Default: Data shall primarily be accessible unless its nature or sensitivity requires higher levels of classification and protection.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The duties and responsibilities of workers – vis-à-vis data classification, access, disclosure, use, modification, or destruction – shall be segregated to prevent any overlap of powers and avoid dispersal of responsibilities.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Conduct impact assessment process: The Business Data Executive shall follow the steps required for an assessment of the potential impact arising from unauthorized access to such data.

mechanisms.name: Data governance/data quality
mechanisms.evidence: Entities shall identify and implement appropriate data protection controls to ensure secure handling, processing, sharing and disposal of data.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Submit an annual report to Data Administrators addressing availability, integrity and confidentiality of classified data.

mechanisms.name: Access control

mechanisms.name: Data retention
mechanisms.evidence: A schedule defining the retention period of all data shall be prepared.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data

title: UK Government's Guidelines for AI Procurement

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Comply with the principles of non-discrimination, equal treatment and proportionality.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Defining the public benefit goal provides an anchor for the overall project and procurement process.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Maximise transparency in AI decision-making to give users confidence that an AI system functions well.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Establish appropriate oversight mechanisms to allow scrutiny of AI systems throughout their lifecycle.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: Must comply with the principles of non-discrimination, equal treatment and proportionality.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Be transparent about your AI project and the tools, data and algorithms you will be using.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Apply the Data Ethics Framework - Principle 6: Make your work transparent and be accountable.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Encourage broad participation which are open and accessible to all.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Ensure data governance mechanisms are in place from the start of the procurement process.

principles.name: Explainability/interpretability
principles.evidence: Encourage explainability and interpretability of algorithms and make this one of your design criteria.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Operational or service staff must have enough knowledge of or training on the AI system to understand how to use it and act on its outputs.

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Focus on proportionality in your approach and do not impose unnecessary burdens.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Conduct initial AI impact assessments at the start of the procurement process.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: You can also consider the requirement for independent audits of the algorithms.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Ensure that knowledge transfer and training is part of your requirement.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Adhere to the Tech Code of Practice and Government Design Principles, the Data Ethics Framework and other relevant standards.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Mechanisms to feed back into the data model are crucial to ensure ethical use.

mechanisms.name: Procurement requirements
mechanisms.evidence: Drafting your requirement can drive innovation and set the foundations for the effective, responsible and ethical deployment of AI technologies.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Ensure that your approach can withstand scrutiny.

inventory.summary: The UK Government's Guidelines for AI Procurement emphasize fairness, transparency, and public interest in AI deployment. They require impact assessments, data governance, and training to ensure ethical use. The guidelines promote inclusivity and accountability, aiming to build trust and ensure safety in AI systems.

title: Beijing Consensus on AI and Education

inventory.summary: The Beijing Consensus on AI and Education emphasizes the integration of AI in education to achieve inclusive and equitable quality education, aligned with the Sustainable Development Goals. It highlights ethical principles such as transparency, non-discrimination, and privacy, advocating for human-centered AI development. The policy proposes mechanisms like capacity building and international cooperation to ensure AI's responsible use in education, promoting lifelong learning and reducing the digital divide.

The policies emphasize transparency, accountability, and inclusiveness, particularly for unbanked and underbanked households.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes a human rights-based approach to AI, focusing on inclusivity, sustainability, and peace. It establishes mechanisms like the Women4Ethical AI platform and the Business Council for Ethics of AI to promote ethical practices and accountability in AI development and use. The policy mandates the implementation of an Ethical Impact Assessment tool to ensure AI respects human rights and ethical standards.

values.name: Competitiveness

values.name: Public interest/common good

values.name: Trust

values.evidence: The further development of the Internet of Things and big data pose also important trust and security challenges for any company and for public acceptance.

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: Digital innovations are a key enabler for meeting the objectives of many of our societal challenges from sustainable health systems to the improvement of resource and energy efficiency.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: The purpose of this Communication is therefore to reinforce the EU's competitiveness in digital technologies and to ensure that every industry in Europe, in whichever sector, wherever situated, and no matter of what size can fully benefit from digital innovations.

principles.name: Interoperability
principles.evidence: There is a need to accelerate the development of common standards and interoperable solutions.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: The proposed actions are expected to mobilise close to 50 B€ of public and private investment in the next 5 years, explore and adapt when needed the legislative framework and reinforce coordination of efforts on skills and quality jobs in the digital age.

principles.name: Multi-stakeholder governance
principles.evidence: The focus is on actions with a clear European value added building on, complementing and ensuring the scaling up of national initiatives. It is based on the engagement of all relevant stakeholders, namely large, mid-size and small companies from all industrial sectors, the digital supply industry, social partners, Member States and regions.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The initiative will give Europe a global lead in data infrastructures and services, and ensure that European science, technology and industry reap the full benefits of data-driven science.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The Communication on Priorities for ICT Standardisation identifies the essential ICT standards and presents measures to accelerate their development in support of digital innovations across the economy.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The gap between the demand for, and availability of digitally skilled workers in Europe is growing. Digital innovations have also a great potential for additional jobs creation in industry with the growth of new businesses and by helping preserve and re-shore industrial jobs.

mechanisms.name: Public-private partnerships
mechanisms.evidence: Public private partnerships on innovation and strategic R&D, will be established and reinforced to ensure EU-wide industry academia collaboration involving stakeholders across value chains.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The Commission will regularly report on the progress of the actions.

mechanisms.name: Digital Innovation Hubs
mechanisms.evidence: The Commission plans to focus 500M€ investment from Horizon 2020 on digital innovation hubs.

inventory.summary: The policy document 'Digitising European Industry' outlines the European Union's strategy to enhance competitiveness and innovation in digital technologies. It emphasizes the importance of interoperability, inclusiveness, and multi-stakeholder governance to ensure that all industries can benefit from digital advancements. The policy proposes mechanisms such as technical standards, public-private partnerships, and digital innovation hubs to foster collaboration and investment in digital innovations across Europe.

It emphasizes values such as human rights, fairness, and safety, and promotes principles like transparency and accountability. title: Assuring a Responsible Future for AI

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: AI must be developed and deployed in a safe and responsible way with its benefits more widely shared.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: Concerns around bias and discrimination, which are frequently cited risks in this sector.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The use of AI poses risks; for example, bias, privacy, and other socio-economic impacts.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: AI assurance can help to demonstrate the safety and trustworthiness of AI systems.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: AI assurance provides tools and techniques to measure, evaluate and communicate the trustworthiness of AI systems.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: AI is transforming the way we live and work, and rapid developments in its capabilities provide exciting new opportunities to improve the lives of UK citizens.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Participants felt that, if assurance were delivered only by an AI developer that is profit motivated, it would not be trustworthy.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Who is accountable when it goes wrong? We need a body we can trust, not the makers of this stuff.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Participants wanted more information about assurance for high-risk use cases.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: The benefits shared widely.

principles.name: Interoperability
principles.evidence: The use of differing frameworks and terminology between different sectors and jurisdictions has also fragmented the AI governance landscape.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Without access to AI models and collaboration with AI developers, third-party AI assurance providers will not be able to produce appropriate assurance tools.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: The need for third-party AI assurance that is high-quality, independent, and deemed trustworthy.

mechanisms.name: Certification/conformity assessment
mechanisms.evidence: AI accreditation services may become a third group of products provided in this market in the future.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Developing an AI Essentials Toolkit to support startups and SMEs to engage with AI assurance.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The importance of technical standards and the ability to develop accreditations against them.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: AI assurance provides tools and techniques to measure, evaluate and communicate the risks posed by AI.

mechanisms.name: Other: AI Assurance Platform
mechanisms.evidence: Developing an AI Assurance Platform to provide a one-stop-shop for information on AI assurance.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes the responsible development and deployment of AI, focusing on safety, trust, and equity. It highlights the importance of AI assurance to mitigate risks and ensure compliance with standards, proposing mechanisms like third-party audits and certification to build a trustworthy AI ecosystem.

title: G7 Toolkit for Artificial Intelligence in the Public Sector

values.name: Human rights

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Governments are aware of the risks to personal data protection, security and safety.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The toolkit aims to support and guide governments in developing, deploying, and using AI in the public sector in a safe, secure, and trustworthy manner.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Governments need to ensure their development, deployment and use in the public sector are safe, secure, and trustworthy.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Governments play a key role in fostering innovation, growth, and public value.

values.name: Accountability
values.evidence: AI can help improve the efficiency of internal operations, the effectiveness of policymaking, the responsiveness of public services, and overall transparency and accountability.

principles.name: Transparency

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: AI can help improve the efficiency of internal operations, the effectiveness of policymaking, the responsiveness of public services, and overall transparency and accountability.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Governments need to ensure their development, deployment and use in the public sector are safe, secure, and trustworthy.

mechanisms.evidence: G7 members have implemented additional safeguards to enable the safe, secure, and trustworthy, development, deployment, and use of AI.

mechanisms.evidence: G7 members report involving a broad range of stakeholders in designing their AI strategies, through e.g. public consultations, stakeholder outreach, and public requests for comment.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: AI skills frameworks are being expanded to address not only technical expertise, but also to build the talent of the leadership.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Monitoring tools are being introduced to ensure AI trustworthiness and safety.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes the ethical use of AI, focusing on transparency, data protection, and human rights. It proposes mechanisms like capacity building and international cooperation to address risks such as bias, discrimination, and privacy violations, ensuring AI systems are developed and used responsibly.

values.name: Trust

inventory.summary: The Generative AI Evaluation Sandbox in Singapore aims to foster trust and safety in AI by developing evaluation benchmarks and promoting transparency and inclusiveness. It involves global stakeholders in a collaborative effort to build evaluation capabilities and establish standards for responsible AI use, with a focus on cultural diversity and public interest.

title: Review Into Bias in Algorithmic Decision-making

values.name: Fairness/Justice/Equity
values.evidence: Fairness is a highly prized human value. Societies in which individuals can flourish need to be held together by practices and institutions that are regarded as fair.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: The approach we take to tackling biased algorithms in recruitment, for example, must form part of, and be consistent with, the way we understand and tackle discrimination in recruitment more generally.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Transparency is key to helping organisations build and maintain public trust.

values.name: Public interest/Common good
values.evidence: Making fair and unbiased decisions is not only good for the individuals involved, but it is good for business and society.

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: There is a clear requirement for strong democratic oversight.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency is key to helping organisations build and maintain public trust.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Organisational leaders need to be clear that they retain accountability for decisions made by their organisations.

principles.name: Human oversight/Human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: There are some aspects of decision-making where human judgement, including the ability to be sensitive and flexible to the unique circumstances of an individual, will remain crucial.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: The use of data from non-traditional sources could enable population groups who have historically found it difficult to access credit.

principles.name: Data governance/Data quality
principles.evidence: Data is needed to monitor outcomes and identify bias, but data on protected characteristics is not available often enough.

principles.name: Due diligence
principles.evidence: Good, anticipatory governance is crucial here. Many of the high profile cases of algorithmic bias could have been anticipated with careful evaluation and mitigation of the potential risks.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Data Protection Impact Assessments and Equality Impact Assessments can help with structuring thinking and documenting the steps taken.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/Third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: We recommend that there should be clear standards for anticipating and monitoring bias, for auditing algorithms and for addressing problems.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Improving diversity across a range of roles involved in the development and deployment of algorithmic decision-making tools is an important part of protecting against bias.

mechanisms.name: Standards/Technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Regulators and industry bodies need to work together with wider society to agree best practice within their industry and establish appropriate regulatory standards.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/Reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Organisations must be particularly mindful to ensure they are meeting the appropriate legislative responsibilities around automated decision-making and reasonable adjustments for candidates with disabilities.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/Redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: We must ensure decisions can be scrutinised, explained and challenged so that our current laws and frameworks do not lose effectiveness.

inventory.summary: The policy focuses on addressing algorithmic bias in decision-making, emphasizing fairness, transparency, and accountability. It proposes mechanisms like impact assessments and algorithmic audits to ensure ethical innovation and public trust. The policy highlights the need for human oversight and improved data governance to mitigate bias and promote inclusivity.

title: Biological Data Storage, Access and Sharing Policy of India

values.name: Human rights

inventory.summary: The Biological Data Storage, Access and Sharing Policy of India emphasizes the ethical sharing of data generated from public funds, prioritizing human rights, privacy, and public good. It mandates transparency, accountability, and informed consent, with mechanisms for data governance, auditing, and complaints handling. The policy aligns with international frameworks but prioritizes national policies when conflicts arise.

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: A human-centred approach to AI upholds Australia’s responsibility to human rights protections.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Upholding diversity, inclusion and fairness.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: Bias becomes problematic or ‘unwanted’ when it results in unfavourable treatment for people or groups.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: You must have appropriate data governance, privacy and cybersecurity measures in place.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Protect people and communities from harms.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Create trust with users. Give people, society and other organisations confidence that you are using AI safely and responsibly.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The standard is designed to help organisations ensure AI systems serve all people in Australia.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Be transparent with other organisations across the AI supply chain about data, models and systems.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Establish, implement, and publish an accountability process including governance, internal capability and a strategy for regulatory compliance.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Enable human control or intervention in an AI system to achieve meaningful human oversight.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Engage your stakeholders and evaluate their needs and circumstances, with a focus on safety, diversity, inclusion and fairness.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Protect AI systems, and implement data governance measures to manage data quality and provenance.

principles.name: Risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Establish and implement a risk management process to identify and mitigate risks.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Begin with the full range of potential harms with information from a stakeholder impact assessment.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Keep and maintain records to allow third parties to assess compliance with guardrails.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Set up the required accountability processes to guide your organisation’s safe and responsible use of AI, including any training your organisation will need.

mechanisms.name: Procurement requirements
mechanisms.evidence: The 10 guardrails include procurement guidance to ensure AI suppliers and developers are aligning to the guardrails through contractual agreements.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Test AI models and systems to evaluate model performance and monitor the system once deployed.

inventory.summary: The Voluntary AI Safety Standard in Australia provides guidance for safe and responsible AI use, focusing on human rights, fairness, and transparency. It establishes voluntary guardrails for organisations to manage risks and ensure accountability, with an emphasis on human oversight and stakeholder engagement. The standard aligns with international frameworks to support consistent practices across jurisdictions.
