referenced_frameworks: EU Guidelines for Ethical Use of AI in Education
inventory.summary: The policy establishes a committee to guide the ethical use of AI in education, emphasizing responsibility, safety, and public interest. It proposes training and monitoring mechanisms to ensure AI's beneficial integration into educational processes, referencing EU and UNESCO guidelines.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: AI assurance can help to provide the basis for consumers to trust the products they buy.

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: AI systems should function in a robust, secure and safe way.

values.name: Fairness/Justice/Equity
values.evidence: AI systems should not undermine the legal rights of individuals or organisations, discriminate unfairly against individuals, or create unfair market outcomes.

values.name: Public interest/Common good
values.evidence: The UK government is taking action to ensure that we can reap the benefits of AI while mitigating potential risks and harms.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: AI systems should be appropriately transparent and explainable.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Governance measures should be in place to ensure effective oversight of the supply of AI systems, with clear lines of accountability.

principles.name: Contestability/Right to appeal
principles.evidence: Users, affected third parties and actors in the AI lifecycle should be able to contest an AI decision or outcome.

principles.name: Robustness/Reliability
principles.evidence: AI systems should function in a robust, secure and safe way.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: A multi-disciplinary and socio-technical approach to ensure that human values and ethical considerations are built-in throughout the AI development lifecycle.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: Supporting cross-border trade in AI will also require a well-developed ecosystem of AI assurance approaches.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Algorithmic impact assessment: Used to anticipate the wider effects of a system/product on the environment, equality, human rights, data protection, or other outcomes.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/Third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Bias audit: Assesses the inputs and outputs of algorithmic systems to determine if there is unfair bias.

mechanisms.name: Certification/Conformity assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Conformity assessment demonstrates whether a product or system meets relevant requirements.

mechanisms.name: Standards/Technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Global technical standards allow assurance users to trust the evidence and conclusions presented by assurance providers.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The AI Standards Hub is dedicated to knowledge sharing, community and capacity building.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Regulators are also implementing a range of sandboxes and prize challenges to support regulatory innovation in AI.

inventory.summary: The policy document outlines the UK's approach to AI assurance, emphasizing the importance of trust, safety, and fairness in AI systems. It proposes a range of mechanisms, including impact assessments and algorithmic audits, to ensure AI systems are developed and deployed responsibly. The document highlights the need for transparency, accountability, and international cooperation to build a robust AI assurance ecosystem.

title: G7 Toolkit for Artificial Intelligence in the Public Sector

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: Governments are aware of the evolving and complex challenges that digital technologies, including AI, pose with respect to protecting human rights.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Governments are aware of the risks to personal data protection, security and safety.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The toolkit aims to support G7 members in navigating the complexities of AI integration within the public sector, providing a comprehensive guide to good practices, governance frameworks, and policy options to strengthen trust in public institutions.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Governments must ensure their development, deployment and use in the public sector are safe, secure, and trustworthy.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Governments play a key role in fostering innovation, growth, and public value.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The deployment of AI in and by the public sector can improve transparency and accountability.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: AI offers significant potential benefits, including enhancing transparency and accountability.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Governments have a crucial role in leading the development, deployment, and use of safe, secure, and trustworthy AI systems.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Inclusive approaches help build trust among users, governments, and other relevant stakeholders.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Efforts are underway to build the necessary foundations for effective and responsible use of AI, which include strengthening infrastructure and data governance.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Governments must manage the risks associated with AI, including bias and discrimination; denial of individual autonomy, recourse and rights.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Incremental and experimental approaches entail engaging stakeholders throughout the development phase, evaluating user needs, assessing data availability and quality, and continuously monitoring progress from the prototyping and piloting phases (e.g. through ex-ante impact assessments).

mechanisms.name: Ethics board/committee
mechanisms.evidence: G7 members have implemented additional safeguards to enable the safe, secure, and trustworthy, development, deployment, and use of AI.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Existing governance frameworks address a variety of issues ranging from AI use, data protection, privacy, and data sharing, to freedom of information.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: AI skills frameworks are being expanded to address not only technical expertise, but also to build the talent of the leadership.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Monitoring tools are being introduced to ensure AI trustworthiness and safety.

mechanisms.name: Procurement requirements
mechanisms.evidence: An increasing number of dedicated frameworks and guidelines for AI procurement are emerging that include requirements related to the trustworthiness of AI.

referenced_frameworks: UNESCO Recommendation on the Ethics of Artificial Intelligence
inventory.summary: The G7 Toolkit for AI in the Public Sector aims to guide governments in the safe, secure, and trustworthy use of AI, emphasizing human rights, privacy, and public trust. It proposes principles like transparency and accountability, and mechanisms such as impact assessments and procurement guidelines, to ensure ethical AI deployment in public services.

title: Personal Data Breach Incidents Procedural Guide

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The Guide outlines procedures to deal with personal data breaches and reduce the consequences and risks influencing Data Subjects.

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: The Controller shall notify the Data Subjects without undue delay if this results in damage to their data or conflicts with their rights or interests.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: If the breach damage extends to a large group of people at the national level, the Controller may notify the Data Subject by other means.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The Controller is required to compile a notice that includes a description of the personal data breach.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The notice provided to the Data Subject shall be in a clear and simple manner.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: The Controller shall implement response and containment procedures for personal data breach incident.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The Controller shall retain copies of the documents submitted to SDAIA regarding incidents of personal data breach.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: A description of risks arising from personal data breach, detailing actual or potential consequences and risks to personal data or the Data Subject.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall notify the Data Subjects without undue delay if this results in damage to their data.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall retain copies of the documents submitted to SDAIA regarding incidents of personal data breach.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The Controller shall take all corrective actions to contain personal data breach incidents, in accordance with lessons learned from it.

inventory.summary: The Personal Data Breach Incidents Procedural Guide by SDAIA outlines mandatory procedures for handling data breaches, emphasizing privacy protection and accountability. It requires timely notification to affected individuals and authorities, and mandates documentation and evaluation of incidents to prevent future occurrences.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: By considering risks and building in safeguards during the early stages of development, it is possible to establish trust in a product or service.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency is a vital component to hold services accountable for content they host or use to train their systems.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Safety by Design is built on three core principles: Service provider responsibility, User empowerment and autonomy, and Transparency and accountability.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: It is important that humans are appropriately trained to conduct this work and feed in diverse views.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Consulting stakeholders from multiple sectors and collaborating with the user community, including those who are typically under-represented.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Developers must consider the content and quality of their data sources, as well as ethical and legal concerns.

principles.name: Safety by Design
principles.evidence: Safety by Design is built on three core principles: Service provider responsibility, User empowerment and autonomy, and Transparency and accountability.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: It is important to conduct risk assessments, anticipate how the model may be misused by individuals and establish safety policies and practices prior to release.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Developers should ‘red-team’ or ‘stress test’ the system by considering the avenues for possible misuse.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Developers should also consider graduated approaches to release, including regulatory sandboxes, to understand how the model performs in controlled conditions.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: It is important that humans are appropriately trained to conduct this work and feed in diverse views.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Transparency is a vital component to hold services accountable for content they host or use to train their systems, including by documentation through annual reports.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes the importance of balancing the benefits and risks of generative AI, focusing on safety, transparency, and accountability. It advocates for a Safety by Design approach, encouraging stakeholder consultation and proactive risk management to prevent and address online harms.

values.name: Innovation
values.evidence: Our regulatory approach will be a key tool in reaching this ambition. A regulatory framework that is proportionate, light-touch and forward-looking is essential to keep pace with the speed of developments in these technologies.

values.name: Public trust
values.evidence: Such an approach will drive innovation by offering businesses the clarity and confidence they need to grow while making sure we boost public trust.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Our ambition is to support responsible innovation in AI - unleashing the full potential of new technologies, while keeping people safe and secure.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: We expect well governed AI to be used with due consideration to concepts of fairness and transparency.

values.name: Accountability
values.evidence: We expect all actors in the AI lifecycle to appropriately manage risks to safety and to provide for strong accountability.

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Our approach will also be risk-based and proportionate.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: For example, around the need for improved transparency and explainability in relation to decisions made by AI.

principles.name: Risk-based approach
principles.evidence: We propose to focus on addressing issues where there is clear evidence of real risk or missed opportunities.

principles.name: Coherence
principles.evidence: We propose to establish a set of cross-sectoral principles tailored to the distinct characteristics of AI.

principles.name: Adaptability
principles.evidence: We propose to set out the cross-sectoral principles on a non-statutory basis in the first instance so our approach remains adaptable.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: We welcome views from AI practitioners and disruptors across the business landscape.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: We will ask that regulators consider lighter touch options, such as guidance or voluntary measures, in the first instance.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The government is also already taking steps to develop world leading AI standards in the UK.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The CDEI published a roadmap towards building a world-leading AI assurance ecosystem in the UK.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: We will engage with regulators to ensure that they proactively embed considerations of innovation, competition and proportionality through their implementation and any subsequent enforcement of the framework.

mechanisms.name: International cooperation
mechanisms.evidence: We will support cooperation on key issues, including through the Council of Europe, OECD working groups and the Global Partnership on AI.

inventory.summary: The UK AI Regulation White Paper outlines a pro-innovation, risk-based approach to AI governance, emphasizing adaptability, coherence, and proportionality. title: National Strategy on R&D and Application of AI

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Nâng cao năng lực và hiệu quả hoạt động của các cơ quan, đơn vị thực hiện chính sách bảo hiểm thất nghiệp... để chính sách bảo hiểm thất nghiệp thực sự trở thành công cụ chủ yếu quản trị thị trường lao động.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Chỉ số đánh giá mức độ hài lòng của người tham gia bảo hiểm thất nghiệp đạt mức 85%.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Tăng cường thanh tra, kiểm tra việc chấp hành pháp luật tại các cơ quan, đơn vị thực hiện bảo hiểm thất nghiệp.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Hằng năm có kế hoạch thanh tra, kiểm tra nhằm kịp thời phát hiện và xử lý nghiêm vi phạm của các cơ quan, tổ chức, cá nhân trong lĩnh vực bảo hiểm thất nghiệp.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: 100% người lao động đang đóng bảo hiểm thất nghiệp bị chấm dứt hợp đồng lao động hoặc hợp đồng làm việc... được tư vấn miễn phí khi có nhu cầu.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Thực hiện chia sẻ, kết nối thông tin, dữ liệu giữa các cơ quan quản lý nhà nước về đầu tư, tài chính, thuế, lao động...

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: Tăng cường học tập, chia sẻ kinh nghiệm, hỗ trợ kỹ thuật về xây dựng chính sách và thực thi bảo hiểm thất nghiệp... của các tổ chức quốc tế.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Xây dựng kế hoạch đào tạo, nâng cao trình độ chuyên môn, nghiệp vụ về bảo hiểm thất nghiệp... cho đội ngũ nhân sự thực hiện bảo hiểm thất nghiệp.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Hằng năm, tổ chức đánh giá việc thực hiện các quy định của pháp luật về bảo hiểm thất nghiệp...

mechanisms.name: Penalties/sanctions/enforcement
mechanisms.evidence: Xử lý nghiêm vi phạm của các cơ quan, tổ chức, cá nhân trong lĩnh vực bảo hiểm thất nghiệp.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: Thực hiện chia sẻ, kết nối thông tin, dữ liệu giữa các cơ quan quản lý nhà nước...

mechanisms.name: Other: Financial autonomy for service centers
mechanisms.evidence: Hoàn thiện cơ chế tài chính về bảo hiểm thất nghiệp trên cơ sở chuyển đổi trung tâm dịch vụ việc làm thành đơn vị sự nghiệp công lập thực hiện tự đảm bảo chi hoạt động thường xuyên.

inventory.summary: The National Strategy on R&D and Application of AI in Viet Nam emphasizes enhancing the capacity and effectiveness of unemployment insurance policies to serve the public interest and improve labor market management. The policy mandates mechanisms for training, data sharing, and enforcement to ensure effective implementation.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes the importance of aligning AI development with fundamental European values such as human rights, fairness, and inclusivity. It advocates for a human-centric approach to AI, ensuring transparency, accountability, and risk-based regulation to protect against discrimination and uphold public interest. The policy also highlights the need for international cooperation and the establishment of standards to maintain European competitiveness in AI.

inventory.summary: The National Occupational Standard Framework for Data and Artificial Intelligence in Saudi Arabia aims to standardize and improve occupational practices in the AI sector. It emphasizes developing human capabilities, aligning with strategic objectives, and incorporating international best practices. The framework implicitly supports values like trust, safety, and public interest, while promoting principles such as accountability, transparency, and data governance.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence

inventory.summary: The policy outlines Denmark's initiative to establish a national AI innovation centre in collaboration with NVIDIA, focusing on enhancing research and innovation in healthcare, life sciences, and the green transition. It emphasizes sustainability, security, and public access to AI resources, aiming to leverage AI for societal benefits while ensuring data governance and international cooperation.

inventory.summary: The Centre for Artificial Intelligence in Society (CAISA) in Denmark aims to integrate AI responsibly within democratic frameworks, emphasizing trust, public interest, and societal cohesion. It promotes interdisciplinary collaboration and international cooperation to address ethical dilemmas and ensure accountability in AI deployment. The initiative includes capacity building and long-term research projects to guide AI's development in alignment with democratic values.

inventory.summary: The NIST Principles for Explainable AI focus on establishing foundational principles for explainable AI systems to enhance trustworthiness. The policy emphasizes the importance of explainability, transparency, and accountability, proposing standards and evaluation methods to ensure AI systems operate within their designed limits and provide understandable explanations to users.

title: Government by Algorithm: AI in Federal Administrative Agencies

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: AI tools hold the promise of more accurate and consistent government decisions, their opacity also creates myriad legal puzzles because of administrative law’s core commitment to transparency and reason-giving when government takes actions that affect rights.

values.name: Transparency
values.evidence: A crucial question will be how to subject such tools to meaningful accountability and thus ensure their fidelity to legal norms of transparency, reason-giving, and non-discrimination.

values.name: Accountability
values.evidence: AI poses deep accountability challenges. When public officials deny benefits or make decisions affecting the public’s rights, the law generally requires them to explain why.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: A crucial question will be how to subject such tools to meaningful accountability and thus ensure their fidelity to legal norms of transparency, reason-giving, and non-discrimination.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: AI promises to transform how government agencies do their work, making government performance more efficient and effective.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: A crucial question will be how to subject such tools to meaningful accountability and thus ensure their fidelity to legal norms of transparency, reason-giving, and non-discrimination.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: AI poses deep accountability challenges. When public officials deny benefits or make decisions affecting the public’s rights, the law generally requires them to explain why.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Growing sophistication and power of AI is nudging agencies toward fully automated decision-making, leaving progressively less to human discretion and judgment.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: AI has the potential to raise distributive concerns and fuel political anxieties.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: AI tools are already improving agency operations across the full range of governance tasks, including extracting useable information from the government’s massive data streams.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: A promising candidate is to require agencies to engage in prospective 'benchmarking' of AI tools by reserving a random hold-out sample of cases for human decision.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Fully leveraging agency use of AI will require significant public investment to draw needed human capital and update outmoded data and computing systems.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Benchmarking of AI tools by reserving a random hold-out sample of cases for human decision, thus providing critical information to smoke out when an algorithm has gone astray.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Policymakers should also consider other interventions.

mechanisms.name: Multi-stakeholder governance
mechanisms.evidence: The research team included a diverse set of lawyers, law students, computer scientists, and social scientists with the capacity to analyze these cutting-edge issues from technical, legal, and policy angles.

inventory.summary: The policy document emphasizes the ethical use of AI in federal agencies, focusing on transparency, accountability, and fairness. It highlights the need for internal capacity building and proposes mechanisms like impact assessments and algorithmic audits to ensure responsible AI deployment. The document underscores the importance of balancing innovation with legal and ethical standards to protect public interest.

title: Resolution on a Comprehensive European Industrial Policy on Artificial Intelligence and Robotics

values.name: Human dignity
values.evidence: AI developments should preserve the dignity, autonomy and self-determination of the individual.

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: The European framework for AI must be developed with full respect for the rights enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: AI should be developed in a human-centred approach with the aim of supporting humans at work and at home.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: Machine learning raises challenges in terms of ensuring non-discrimination.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The principles of data protection, privacy and security must be respected.

values.name: Autonomy/self-determination
values.evidence: AI developments should preserve the dignity, autonomy and self-determination of the individual.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: AI is enabling innovation, productivity, competitiveness and wellbeing.

values.evidence: Improve consumer experience and trust in AI technologies and robotics.

values.evidence: Cybersecurity is vital for ensuring that data is not maliciously corrupted or misused.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: AI has the potential to enrich our lives and further our capabilities for the common good.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency in decision-making is a concern about AI and robotics.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Those involved in AI development must be prepared to accept legal liability for the quality of the technology.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: AI introduction in health must always be based on the ‘man operates machine’ principle of responsibility.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Safeguards and the possibility of human control and verification need to be built into automated decision-making.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: AI research should be conducted in accordance with the precautionary principle.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: AI should fully support all European languages to provide equal opportunities.

principles.name: Interoperability
principles.evidence: Interoperability and data accuracy are important for reliability and security standards.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Data quality, together with algorithmic design, should prevent bias.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: A coordinated approach at European level is urgently needed to compete globally.

principles.name: Multi-stakeholder governance
principles.evidence: The Commission committed to developing draft AI guidelines in cooperation with stakeholders within the AI alliance.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Welcomes the use of regulatory sandboxes to introduce innovative new ideas.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Urges Member States to focus on retraining workers in industries affected by automation.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Encourages research into AI to focus on detection of accidentally or maliciously corrupted AI.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: A data-driven AI ecosystem could comprise pan-European initiatives launched on open standards.

mechanisms.name: Procurement requirements
mechanisms.evidence: Notes the importance of greater investment in this field to remain competitive.

mechanisms.name: Sectoral regulation
mechanisms.evidence: Urges the Commission to not allow EU funding for weaponised AI.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: Calls for public authorities to ensure ways of producing, sharing and governing data.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes the ethical development of AI and robotics, focusing on human dignity, rights, and well-being. Mechanisms like regulatory sandboxes and training are proposed to ensure responsible AI integration, with a strong emphasis on international cooperation and multi-stakeholder governance.

principles.evidence: Ensure accountability, decisions based on analytical methods or automated processes affecting people should be openly disclosed.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Analytical processes are a tool to inform human decision-making and should never entirely replace human oversight.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility

principles.name: Explainability/interpretability
principles.evidence: Explanations of decisions – and the analytical activities behind them – should be in clear, simple, easy-to-understand language.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Regular assessments to check for bias and other harmful elements, and address any over-reliance on correlations, are essential.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Regular assessments to check for bias and other harmful elements.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Developing data capability helps to create depth of understanding and implement the most useful data tools.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Regular assessments to check for bias and other harmful elements.

mechanisms.name: Consultation
mechanisms.evidence: Consultation with stakeholders and Māori as partners ensures manaakitanga and kaitiakitanga.

inventory.summary: The policy outlines principles for the safe and effective use of data and analytics in New Zealand, emphasizing public benefit, fairness, privacy, and cultural inclusivity. The policy also highlights the importance of stakeholder consultation and capacity building to ensure ethical data practices.

title: Autonomous Vehicles - Code of Practice for Testing in Belgium

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: The Code lists the minimum conditions the competent authorities expect to be respected in order to guarantee road safety and minimise potential risks.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Testing organisations shall compile a report after each test on the public road or in any other public place.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: It is expected that careful testing will contribute to the well-planned development of automated vehicles which...will display exemplary driving behaviour, improving the safety of all road users, and reduce emissions and traffic congestion.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The testing organisation, and by extension all the persons involved, shall ensure that the data protection legislation is complied with.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The responsibility for the safe and orderly testing of the technologies in question on the public road or in any other public places invariably rests always with the testing organisations.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Testing organisations must engage with the competent transport and road authorities with responsibility or competence for the test location.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Conduct a (prior) risk analysis of any tests proposed and develop appropriate risk management strategies.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Testing on the public road shall invariably require the presence of a test driver.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Automated vehicles under test should be fitted with a data recording device that is capable of recording data from the sensor and control systems.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: The test driver or test operator is responsible for the safe operation of the vehicle at all times.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: A (prior) assessment of the impact on privacy of the proposed tests and/or the procedures implemented is not a legal requirement but can be useful.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Testing organisations shall develop and implement procedures to ensure the competency of test drivers and test operators.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Testing organisations shall compile a report after each test on the public road or in any other public place.

mechanisms.name: Insurance/liability framework
mechanisms.evidence: Anyone conducting tests with automated vehicles on public roads or in other public places must be covered by appropriate insurance.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Testing organisations and/or other entities involved are advised to adhere to and apply the security principles as set out in Standard IEC 61508.

inventory.summary: The policy focuses on ensuring the safe and responsible testing of autonomous vehicles in Belgium. It emphasizes safety, accountability, and compliance with data protection laws, requiring risk assessments and robust reporting mechanisms. The policy mandates human oversight during tests and encourages adherence to technical standards to ensure security and reliability.

principles.name: Due diligence

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The Controller shall document the disclosure request and precisely specify the type of personal data to be disclosed.

principles.name: Proportionality
principles.evidence: Disclosure shall be limited to the minimum personal data necessary to achieve its purpose.

mechanisms.name: Documentation

mechanisms.name: Safeguards

title: Guide to the Saudi Personal Data Protection Law for Controllers and Processors

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The PDPL is the key law in the Kingdom in the area of personal data protection.

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: Sensitive data requires additional safeguards and protections as the unauthorized access of such data may cause serious harm to the individual.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: You must ensure that processing is conducted in a manner that is fair, lawful, and transparent and in accordance with the principles of the PDPL.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Establishing a thriving digital economy is one of the key priorities for the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia as per the Saudi Vision 2030.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: You must ensure that processing is conducted in a manner that is fair, lawful, and transparent.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The Controller(s) is/are held ultimately accountable for the processing undertaken.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The PDPL regulates the processing of personal data. It includes regulation of processing of personal data of any type, including sensitive data.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: If you rely on consent as a lawful basis for processing of sensitive data, such consent must be explicit.

principles.name: Purpose limitation
principles.evidence: A Controller is an entity that makes decisions about the purposes and manner of the processing.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: The Guidance does not contain any binding rules or obligations. It does not have the status of a law or a similar legal instrument in the Kingdom.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Regulations, standards, policies and other legal instruments in the data protection area issued by the Saudi Data and AI Authority.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The aim of the Guidance is to clarify the PDPL and provide directions to individuals and organizations for compliance with the PDPL.

mechanisms.name: Penalties/sanctions/enforcement
mechanisms.evidence: You could be exempted from an obligation to comply with the PDPL in limited cases in accordance with the legal instruments issued by the competent authorities in the Kingdom.

inventory.summary: The Saudi Personal Data Protection Law (PDPL) emphasizes privacy and data protection as foundational values, aiming to support a thriving digital economy. It mandates transparency, accountability, and informed consent as key principles, with mechanisms like standards and regulatory guidance to ensure compliance. The policy implicitly supports non-maleficence and public trust by requiring additional safeguards for sensitive data.

mechanisms.evidence: Impact assessment: Used to anticipate the effect of a system on environmental, equality, human rights, data protection, or other outcomes.

mechanisms.name: Impact evaluation
mechanisms.evidence: Impact evaluation: Similar to impact assessments, but are conducted after a system has been implemented.

mechanisms.name: Bias audit
mechanisms.evidence: Bias audit: Assessing the inputs and outputs of algorithmic systems to determine if there is unfair bias.

mechanisms.name: Compliance audit
mechanisms.evidence: Compliance audit: A review of a company’s adherence to internal policies and procedures, or external regulations.

mechanisms.name: Certification
mechanisms.evidence: Certification: A process where an independent body attests that a product, service, organisation or individual has been tested against, and met, objective standards.

mechanisms.name: Conformity assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Conformity assessment includes activities such as testing, inspection and certification.

mechanisms.name: Performance testing
mechanisms.evidence: Performance testing: Used to assess the performance of a system with respect to predetermined quantitative requirements.

mechanisms.name: Formal verification
mechanisms.evidence: Formal verification: Establishes whether a system satisfies some requirements using the formal methods of mathematics.

mechanisms.name: Standards/Technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: The UK AI Standards Hub to champion the use of international standards.

values.name: Trust

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: Differential accuracy can create additional barriers or disincentives for underrepresented groups when accessing key services.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory Framework

mechanisms.name: Complaints/Redress Mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Liberty has been granted an appeal of the high court’s decision.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity Building

mechanisms.name: Standards/Technical Standards
mechanisms.evidence: The ICO has called for a new code of practice to give specific guidance to police forces on how to deploy FRT.

inventory.summary: The Administrative Cloud Strategy (DVS) of Germany focuses on enhancing digital sovereignty through the establishment of interoperable and standardized cloud solutions across federal, state, and local levels. It emphasizes autonomy, privacy, and security, advocating for transparency and open-source software. The strategy mandates the creation of technical standards and modular architectures to ensure efficient and secure data management, aiming to reduce dependencies on major cloud providers.

principles.evidence: Systems must be built to be clearly 'explainable'.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Holds designers, vendors, procurers, developers, owners, and assessors of GenAI systems ethically responsible.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: Holds designers, vendors, procurers, developers, owners, and assessors of GenAI systems ethically responsible.

principles.name: Robustness/Reliability
principles.evidence: Ensures that GenAI systems adhere to set specifications and that they behave as designers intend.

principles.name: Human Oversight/Human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Predefined triggers/alerts should be in place based on system risks, GenAI systems should trigger human oversight.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: GenAI offers solutions to enhance content accessibility.

principles.name: Data Governance/Data Quality
principles.evidence: Ensure data quality checks, cleanse data and validate the integrity of the data.

principles.name: Privacy by Design
principles.evidence: Privacy and security by design should be implemented while building the AI system.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic Auditing/Third-party Audit
mechanisms.evidence: Scrutinize content for factual accuracy and contextual relevance to prevent the dissemination of erroneous information.

mechanisms.name: Certification/Conformity Assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Review all forms of assessment and evaluation to enhance their resilience against AI-aided fraud.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity Building
mechanisms.evidence: Organizations must emphasize to their workforce that existing and upcoming legal requirements remain binding when using GenAI tools.

mechanisms.name: Labelling/Disclosure Requirements
mechanisms.evidence: Employ tools such as watermarks to assist others in identifying content generated by AI.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & Evaluation/Reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Regular updates and refinements to these systems based on feedback and emerging trends will ensure they remain effective against evolving threats.

mechanisms.name: Impact Assessment
mechanisms.evidence: The privacy impact assessment and risk management assessment should be continuously revisited.

mechanisms.name: Risk Classification/Tiered Regulation
mechanisms.evidence: Assess the risks resulting from the use of the GenAI tool according to the AI ethics principles; little or no risk, limited risk, high risk, unacceptable risk.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/Redress Mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Rapid, organization-wide communication is key to their successful implementation.

inventory.summary: The Generative Artificial Intelligence Guidelines for Saudi Arabia emphasize ethical principles such as fairness, safety, privacy, and transparency. The policy outlines mechanisms for risk mitigation, including algorithmic auditing, certification, and training, to ensure responsible GenAI use. It aims to build public trust and promote the common good while safeguarding human rights and environmental sustainability.

values.name: Fairness/Justice/Equity

values.name: Sustainability/Environment

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: AI systems should be designed with mechanisms and controls that provide the possibility to govern and monitor their outcomes.

values.name: Well-being/Beneficence
values.evidence: AI systems should contribute to empowering and complementing social and environmental progress.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: AI systems should be designed with mechanisms and controls that provide the possibility to govern and monitor their outcomes.

principles.name: Accountability

principles.evidence: The functionality of an AI system should not be limited to a specific group based on gender, race, religion, disability, age, or sexual orientation.

principles.name: Robustness/Reliability

values.evidence: ปัญญาประดิษฐ์ควรถูกสร้างและใช้งานเพื่อสร้างประโยชน์และความผาสุกให้แก่มนุษย์

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: ปัญญาประดิษฐ์ควรถูกสร้างเพื่อบริการ แต่ไม่ควรถูกใช้เพื่อหลอกลวง ต่อต้าน และคุกคามมนุษย์

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: เพื่อท าให้ปัญญาประดิษฐ์มีความน่าเชื่อถือ มั่นคงปลอดภัย

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: ปัญญาประดิษฐ์ควรได้รับการออกแบบโดยใช้หลักการป้องกันความเสี่ยง เพื่อป้องกันการโจมตีจากภัยคุกคาม

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: เพื่อประโยชน์ต่อส่วนรวมเป็นส าคัญ

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: ปัญญาประดิษฐ์ควรได้รับการวิจัย ออกแบบ พัฒนา ให้บริการและใช้งานด้วยความโปร่งใส

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: ผู้วิจัย ผู้ออกแบบ ผู้พัฒนา ผู้ให้บริการและผู้ใช้งานปัญญาประดิษฐ์ ควรมีภาระความรับผิดชอบ (Accountability) ต่อผลกระทบที่เกิดขึ้น

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: ออกแบบปัญญาประดิษฐ์ควรใช้หลักการมนุษย์เป็นศูนย์กลางและเป็นผู้ตัดสินใจ

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: การออกแบบและพัฒนาปัญญาประดิษฐ์ควรคำนึงถึงความหลากหลาย หลีกเลี่ยงการผูกขาด

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: การออกแบบและพัฒนาปัญญาประดิษฐ์จึงควรคำนึงถึงหลักการรักษาความมั่นคงปลอดภัยและการป้องกันข้อมูล ส่วนตัว

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: หน่วยงานรัฐควรวางแผนกำกับดูแลการพัฒนาและให้ความร่วมมือกับนานาชาติ

principles.name: Purpose limitation
principles.evidence: ปัญญาประดิษฐ์ไม่ควรถูกใช้ในการกำหนดชะตาชีวิตของมนุษย์

mechanisms.name: Ethics board/committee
mechanisms.evidence: ควรรับคำปรึกษาจากคณะกรรมการอิสระ ผู้เชี่ยวชาญและสถาบันการศึกษา

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: ควรสร้างกลไกที่ทำให้หน่วยงานควบคุมดูแลการพัฒนาและการใช้งานระบบปัญญาประดิษฐ์มีคณะกรรมการผู้เชี่ยวชาญที่เป็นอิสระ

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: ควรมีการตรวจสอบความเอนเอียงที่สำคัญ

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: ควรให้การศึกษาแก่ประชาชนอย่างต่อเนื่องเพื่อพัฒนาและให้ความรู้ถึงการพัฒนาล่าสุดของปัญญาประดิษฐ์

mechanisms.name: International standards
mechanisms.evidence: ภาครัฐควรสนับสนุนในการสร้างมาตรฐานที่เป็นที่ยอมรับโดยสากล

mechanisms.name: Whistleblower protection
mechanisms.evidence: สร้างกลไกภาระความรับผิดชอบที่เหมาะสมและควบคุมดูแลเพื่อป้องกันหรือลดอัลกอริทึมที่มีความเอนเอียง

inventory.summary: The Thai AI Ethics Guidelines emphasize the importance of aligning AI development with human rights, fairness, and transparency. It advocates for international cooperation, human oversight, and accountability to ensure AI systems are beneficial and secure. The policy draws on global frameworks to promote ethical AI practices that respect privacy and prevent discrimination.

title: Pilots for the Impact Assessment Human Rights and Algorithms

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: The Fundamental Rights and Algorithm Impact Assessment (FRAIA) helps to map the risks to fundamental rights in the use of algorithms.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: The Fundamental Rights and Algorithm Impact Assessment (FRAIA) helps to map the risks to fundamental rights in the use of algorithms.

inventory.summary: The policy focuses on assessing the impact of algorithms on fundamental rights through the established FRAIA mechanism. It aims to identify and address risks to human rights in algorithmic applications, as demonstrated by its application across various government bodies.

inventory.summary: The AI-Triage for General Practitioners policy in the Netherlands focuses on improving efficiency and well-being in healthcare by implementing AI-driven triage systems. It emphasizes human oversight and accessibility, ensuring that healthcare professionals remain involved in the diagnostic process while enhancing patient access to services. The policy includes mechanisms for training and evaluation to support its implementation.

It incorporates principles like explainability and ethics-by-design, aiming to train professionals with a multidisciplinary approach. The program supports international cooperation and multi-stakeholder governance to address AI's societal impacts.

It addresses inequalities in access to digital technologies and supports educators and learners in adapting to the digital age.

title: The Robustness and Explainability of Artificial Intelligence

values.name: Privacy/Data Protection
values.evidence: The study addresses the relationship between the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and artificial intelligence (AI).

values.name: Fairness/Justice/Equity
values.evidence: The ethical principles include autonomy, prevention of harm, fairness and explicability.

values.name: Autonomy/Self-Determination
values.evidence: The ethical principles include autonomy, prevention of harm, fairness and explicability.

values.name: Non-Maleficence/Do No Harm
values.evidence: The ethical principles include autonomy, prevention of harm, fairness and explicability.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Consistent application of data protection principles, when combined with the ability to efficiently use AI technology, can contribute to the success of AI applications, by generating trust and preventing risks.

values.name: Public Interest/Common Good
values.evidence: AI-based citizen-empowering technologies can play an important role in this regard, by enabling citizens not only to protect themselves from unwanted surveillance and 'nudging', but also to detect unlawful practices.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Article 5(1)(a) GDPR: Fairness, transparency.

principles.name: Explainability/Interpretability
principles.evidence: The ethical principles include autonomy, prevention of harm, fairness and explicability.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The principles of risk-prevention and accountability potentially direct the processing of personal data.

principles.name: Human Oversight/Human-in-the-Loop
principles.evidence: AI-based citizen-empowering technologies can play an important role in this regard, by enabling citizens not only to protect themselves from unwanted surveillance and 'nudging'.

principles.name: Precaution/Risk-Based Approach
principles.evidence: The GDPR provisions on preventive measures, and in particular those concerning privacy by design and by default.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: A broad debate is needed involving not only political and administrative authorities, but also civil society and academia.

principles.name: Data Governance/Data Quality
principles.evidence: The GDPR allows for inferences based on personal data, provided that appropriate safeguards are adopted.

principles.name: Informed Consent
principles.evidence: Article 4(11) GDPR: Consent.

principles.name: Purpose Limitation
principles.evidence: Article 5(1)(b) GDPR: Purpose limitation.

principles.name: Other: Reasonableness
principles.evidence: Guidance is needed on profiling and automated decision-making. It seems that an obligation of reasonableness – including normative and reliability aspects – should be imposed on controllers engaging in profiling.

mechanisms.name: Impact Assessment
mechanisms.evidence: It needs to be clarified which AI applications present high risks and therefore require a preventive data protection assessment.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic Auditing/Third-Party Audit
mechanisms.evidence: AI-based citizen-empowering technologies can play an important role in this regard, by enabling citizens not only to protect themselves from unwanted surveillance and 'nudging', but also to detect unlawful practices.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity Building
mechanisms.evidence: Providing guidance requires a multilevel approach, which involves data protection authorities, civil society, representative bodies, specialised agencies, and all stakeholders.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & Evaluation/Reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The successful application of GDPR to AI-application depends heavily on what guidance data protection bodies and other competent authorities will provide to controllers and data subjects.

mechanisms.name: Other: Guidance Provision
mechanisms.evidence: Controllers and data subjects should be provided with guidance on how AI can be applied to personal data consistently with the GDPR.

inventory.summary: The policy document explores the intersection of AI and GDPR, emphasizing the need for ethical principles such as fairness, autonomy, and prevention of harm. It highlights the importance of transparency, accountability, and a risk-based approach in AI governance. The document calls for guidance and impact assessments to ensure AI applications align with data protection principles, while fostering public trust and safeguarding individual rights.

values.name: Human dignity
values.evidence: Serbia needs to develop an irreversible track record in adhering to, upholding and defending the values of respect for human dignity.

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: Serbia must adhere to the values of respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to national and other minorities.

values.name: Democracy
values.evidence: Democracy, human rights and rule of law are fundamental values on which the EU is founded.

values.name: Rule of law
values.evidence: The EU’s commitment to fostering the rule of law extends to Serbia.

values.name: Freedom
values.evidence: Serbia needs to uphold and defend the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law.

values.name: Equality
values.evidence: Serbia needs to uphold and defend the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Encourages Serbian authorities to communicate more actively and unambiguously their commitment to European values in the public debate.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The EU has shown its commitment to the European perspective of Western Balkan countries and mobilised EUR 3.3 billion to address the immediate health crisis and mitigate the economic and social consequences of the COVID-19 pandemic.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Encourages the Serbian authorities to communicate more actively their commitment to European values in public debate and to increase the transparency of their communication.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Calls on Serbia to improve its fight against organised crime and to switch from an approach based on individual cases to a strategy against organisations.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Calls for the continuation of the IPD with the National Assembly of Serbia, facilitated by the European Parliament, with the involvement of all relevant stakeholders and pro-European political forces.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: All political forces, especially the governing authorities, have a responsibility to improve electoral conditions.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Calls on the Serbian Government to appoint a new head of the negotiating team for Serbia’s accession to the European Union as soon as possible.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Calls for effective cooperation with independent and regulatory bodies and increased engagement of the National Assembly in oversight and control of the government and administration.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Calls on the Commission to change its reporting methodology in order to take account of significant backsliding and send a clear message to accession countries.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The EU should continue its cooperation with the Council of Europe to support Serbia in carrying out essential reforms and training regarding justice, the fight against corruption, the promotion of human rights, and the role of free and independent media and civil society, and in monitoring the progress realised in those areas.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The EU should continue its cooperation with the Council of Europe to support Serbia in carrying out essential reforms and training regarding justice.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Encourages further progress to be made, in particular in the area of improving the track record on investigations, indictments and final convictions in high-level corruption cases, and implementing the laws on the prevention of corruption in line with the EU acquis and the recommendations of GRECO.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Calls on the Serbian authorities to address fully all ODIHR recommendations well ahead of the next elections.

mechanisms.name: Ethics board/committee
mechanisms.evidence: Welcomes the establishment of the Working Group for the implementation of ODIHR recommendations.

inventory.summary: The policy document emphasizes the importance of aligning Serbia's governance with EU values such as human dignity, democracy, and rule of law. It calls for increased transparency, accountability, and inclusiveness in Serbia's political processes. Mechanisms like impact assessments and monitoring are required to ensure compliance with EU standards, while training and cooperation with international bodies are proposed to support Serbia's reform efforts.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes the development of ethical frameworks and the establishment of an AI Regulation and Ethics Knowledge Centre to address legal and ethical issues. It focuses on improving data quality and access, and proposes training programs to build capacity in the public sector. The strategy implicitly supports values such as human dignity and trust, and aims to enhance transparency and accountability in AI governance.

title: State Department Guidance on Products or Services With Surveillance Capabilities

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: The U.S. Department of State is committed to the promotion and protection of human rights.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Violating or abusing the right to be free from arbitrary or unlawful interference with privacy.

values.name: Rule of law
values.evidence: Governments that do not demonstrate respect for human rights and rule of law.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Businesses should address adverse human rights impacts with which they are involved.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Products can be used to strengthen government end-user network security in a rights-protecting manner.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Products or services can help resolve urgent challenges facing society.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Businesses should address adverse human rights impacts with which they are involved.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Public Communication: Communication, at least annually, of the business’s commitment to a rigorous internal and external review of human rights risks.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Integrate human rights due diligence into compliance programs, including export compliance programs.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: Assess and Address Risk: The amount and depth of due diligence should be commensurate with the severity and likelihood of an adverse impact.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Establish secure, accessible, and responsive communication channels for internal and external reporting of possible misuse.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Review the IT infrastructure of the destination country to determine level of government access and/or control.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: Mechanisms for individuals to report misuse of the product or service.

principles.name: Due diligence
principles.evidence: Human Rights Due Diligence: For the purpose of this document, 'due diligence' is defined as the process by which a business works to identify, anticipate, prevent, mitigate, and account for how it addresses actual or potential adverse impacts on the human rights of individuals.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Review product or service and conduct assessments to determine if the product or service could be misused to violate or abuse human rights.

mechanisms.name: Grievance mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: Establish secure, accessible, and responsive communication channels for internal and external reporting of possible misuse of a product or service.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Provide routine human rights due diligence training to all employees involved in the transaction.

mechanisms.name: Contractual safeguards
mechanisms.evidence: Include human rights safeguards language in contracts.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Ongoing Assessment of Monitoring and Evaluation: Iterative, responsive, and adaptable process that includes monitoring, evaluation, and feedback loops.

mechanisms.name: Other: Red flag indicators
mechanisms.evidence: A 'red flag' is any information that arises through any source where follow-up, assessment, and/or further due diligence is warranted.

referenced_frameworks: UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights
International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights
inventory.summary: The policy provides guidance for U.S. businesses on integrating human rights due diligence into their operations, particularly when dealing with products or services with surveillance capabilities. It emphasizes the importance of assessing and mitigating risks of human rights abuses, promoting transparency, accountability, and stakeholder engagement. The guidance aligns with international human rights frameworks and suggests mechanisms like impact assessments and grievance channels to ensure ethical practices.

values.name: Innovation
values.evidence: Our economic policy has been focused on fostering Poland’s development by making Polish enterprises more and more innovative.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Creating conditions conducive to the development of a modern economy has been one of this Government’s priorities.

values.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
values.evidence: The entire competition documentation has been radically simplified... more reader-friendly and understandable.

principles.name: Transparency

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: We want to ensure that the application process itself does not create any barriers to innovators.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: We are attentive to entrepreneurs’ voices, and the just-announced Fast Track competition is a proof of that.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Applicants can also receive increased support from the Centre’s experts.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Applicants will have a chance to receive extended project recommendations, and to correct their applications.

mechanisms.name: Sectoral regulation
mechanisms.evidence: Calls for proposals under Fast Track 'Heating devices' and Fast Track 'Innovative environmentally friendly fertilisers' are currently in progress.

inventory.summary: The Fast Track policy in Poland aims to foster innovation by simplifying the application process for EU-funded R&D projects, making it more accessible and transparent. It emphasizes inclusiveness and public interest by reducing barriers for innovators and providing support through expert guidance and sector-specific competitions.

inventory.summary: The National AI Strategy of Indonesia emphasizes a human-centered approach to AI, focusing on societal benefits, privacy, and sustainability. It highlights the importance of inclusiveness, data governance, and international cooperation, proposing mechanisms like training and open data to support these principles.

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: The project aims at tackling climate change and understanding the role of oceans in regulating and sustaining the biosphere.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The project focuses on understanding the ocean and climate change, which are global challenges affecting all of humanity.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Data governance policy for marine biology and oceanographic data, consolidated access to data.

principles.name: Explainability/interpretability
principles.evidence: Causality and explainable models in AI, explainable AI for automatic plankton discovery.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: Involves Inria teams in Chile, Paris, Saclay, and Sophia-Antipolis, and several international partners.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: The project involves a diverse combination of skills, experience, and interests to address a multi-disciplinary project.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: Consolidated access to data and scientific computing software stacks.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: The project involves workshops and meetings to share knowledge and progress.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Annual meetings and workshops to discuss progress and findings.

inventory.summary: The OcéanIA Challenge is a multi-disciplinary project focused on using AI and mathematical modeling to understand the ocean's role in climate change. It emphasizes sustainability and the common good, with principles of data governance, explainability, and international cooperation. The project proposes mechanisms for data sharing and capacity building to achieve its goals.

title: Guidelines for the responsible use of generative AI

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: ensuring that emerging AI technologies are used transparently, responsibly, and in ways that maintain public trust

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: ensure the responsible use of generative artificial intelligence (AI) across government operations

values.name: Public interest/Common good
values.evidence: promoting best practices... support consistent and responsible AI use across multiple government agencies

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: ensuring that emerging AI technologies are used transparently

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: guidance on ethical considerations, data protection, transparency, and accountability in AI deployment

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: ensure the responsible use of generative artificial intelligence

principles.name: Inclusiveness/Accessibility
principles.evidence: support consistent and responsible AI use across multiple government agencies

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: ensures alignment with national digital strategies

mechanisms.name: Multi-stakeholder governance
mechanisms.evidence: government-wide network where experiences, lessons learned, and best practices regarding AI use are actively shared

mechanisms.name: Coordination structure
mechanisms.evidence: Digital Office cooperation and coordination structure, which oversees AI-related initiatives

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: facilitates inter-agency collaboration, and ensures alignment with national digital strategies

inventory.summary: The policy provides guidelines for the responsible use of generative AI in Finland's government operations, emphasizing transparency, accountability, and public trust. It establishes a government-wide network for sharing best practices and a coordination structure to align AI initiatives with national strategies. The approach aims to ensure safe, ethical, and effective AI adoption across public administration.

inventory.summary: Canada's Digital Charter aims to build trust in digital technologies by prioritizing privacy, security, and accountability. It proposes mechanisms to enhance transparency and control over personal data, while promoting innovation and economic growth. The Charter outlines principles to ensure responsible AI use and strong enforcement of privacy laws.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: AI has the potential to contribute significant benefits in a variety of areas through increased economic growth, and solutions to environmental and social challenges.

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: AI systems are carefully designed to prevent them from doing harm.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: AI applications should be ethical, safe, secure, reliable and transparent.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Loss of trust, financial damage and consequences for the functioning of democracy.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The Government’s goal is to make Sweden a leader in harnessing the opportunities that the use of AI can offer, with the aim of strengthening Sweden’s welfare and competitiveness.

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: A cross-cutting theme should be sustainable AI.

values.name: Democracy
values.evidence: Consequences for the functioning of democracy.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), which applies from 25 May 2018, provides strong privacy protection in personal data processing.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The use of AI algorithms must be transparent and comprehensible.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The use of AI requires account to be taken of moral and legal issues.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: Managing the risks in a responsible manner will have a great competitive advantage internationally.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Ethical, safety and security considerations cannot be an afterthought; they must be an integral part of the early design stage.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: AI knowledge and expertise must be available throughout society – in large and small businesses, in municipalities, county councils and government agencies.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: Sweden needs strong relations with leading international AI research environments.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: Risks may arise in the form of incorrect or otherwise undesirable outcomes if data is of low quality.

principles.name: Ethical principles
principles.evidence: Sweden needs to develop rules, standards, norms and ethical principles to guide ethical and sustainable AI and the use of AI.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Opportunities for relevant continuing and further education for practising professionals are therefore necessary.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Sweden needs to push for Swedish and international standards and regulations that promote the use of AI and prevent risks.

mechanisms.name: Pilot projects/testbeds
mechanisms.evidence: Sweden needs pilot projects, testbeds and environments for development of AI applications in the public and private sectors.

mechanisms.name: International cooperation
mechanisms.evidence: Sweden needs to develop partnerships and collaborations on the use of AI applications with other countries, especially within the EU.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: Sweden needs to continue the work on making data available to serve as infrastructure for AI use in areas where it adds value.

inventory.summary: The Swedish national AI policy emphasizes the ethical, safe, and sustainable use of AI to enhance welfare and competitiveness. It highlights the importance of transparency, international cooperation, and data governance, while proposing mechanisms like training and pilot projects to manage AI's risks and benefits. The policy aligns with the EU's GDPR for privacy protection.

inventory.summary: The Explainable AI Program by the Department of Defense focuses on developing AI systems that are transparent and interpretable to enhance trust and effective management by human users. It emphasizes the creation of explainable models and human-computer interfaces to improve understanding and oversight of AI systems, with ongoing evaluation and a toolkit for future development.

title: Discussion Paper on Generative AI - Implications for Trust and Governance

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The practical pathways for governance in this paper seek to advance the global discourse and foster greater collaboration to ensure generative AI is used in a safe and responsible manner, and that the most critical outcome — trust — is sustained.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: This primer presents a policy perspective...to chart the path towards how AI can be harnessed in a trusted manner for the broader public good.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: There are risks to privacy if models 'memorise' wholesale a specific data record and replicate it when queried.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Singapore’s Model AI Governance Framework, for example, is based on the key governance principles - transparency, accountability, fairness, explainability, and robustness.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: To do so, policymakers should enable greater adoption, as well as put in place guardrails to address the risks and ensure safe and responsible use.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Transparency on type of training datasets is an important consideration so that the wider community is aware of the input factors that go into the model.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: A shared responsibility framework among parties in the development lifecycle will clarify accountability and incentivise safer outcomes.

principles.name: Explainability/interpretability
principles.evidence: Singapore’s Model AI Governance Framework, for example, is based on the key governance principles - transparency, accountability, fairness, explainability, and robustness.

principles.name: Robustness/reliability
principles.evidence: Singapore’s Model AI Governance Framework, for example, is based on the key governance principles - transparency, accountability, fairness, explainability, and robustness.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: When fine-tuned using RLHF, language models learn to follow instructions better and generate results that show fewer instances of 'hallucination' and toxicity.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: To make generative AI accessible to all enterprises, especially small and medium enterprises (SMEs), policymakers can help by providing an updated set of guidance for organisations.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: A practical, risk-based and accretive approach will contribute to enhanced trust and safety as AI continues to evolve.

mechanisms.name: Labelling/disclosure requirements
mechanisms.evidence: Labelling/watermarking of AI-generated content will allow consumers of content to make more informed decisions and choices.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Enhanced education and training is also needed to build skills, given the anticipated changes to jobs.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Policymakers can support through facilitating the development of standardised evaluation metrics as well as a corpus of tools and capabilities.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: There is value for independent third-party evaluation and assurance to provide objective assessments.

mechanisms.name: International cooperation
mechanisms.evidence: We need to collaborate globally, and create platforms to bring in diverse stakeholders to the ongoing conversation.

inventory.summary: The policy document outlines a governance framework for generative AI, emphasizing trust, public good, and safety. It proposes principles like transparency, accountability, and robustness, and suggests mechanisms such as labelling, training, and international cooperation to ensure responsible AI use.

title: CDEI Snapshot Paper: AI and Personal Insurance

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Critics say that AI could lead to detrimental outcomes for customers, particularly where it allows or requires the collection and sharing of large data troves, which could impinge on privacy.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Society should have a say in any decision on where to redraw the boundary between acceptable and unacceptable forms of discrimination.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Without greater disclosure, insurers will struggle to build trust with customers.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: More accessible privacy notices, data discrimination audits, and industry-wide registers for third party suppliers of data are all potential measures to ensure AI and data continue to be used for the public good.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Underpinning all of these measures should be a sector-wide commitment to transparency.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Insurers must be mindful of the risks of bias in their AI systems and take steps to mitigate unwarranted discrimination.

principles.name: Informed consent
principles.evidence: The principal objection to the use of observed and inferred data is that it can be captured without the express consent of individuals.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Using AI to produce more accurate risk assessments, for example, could make insurance products more accessible to individuals previously deemed too risky.

mechanisms.name: Data governance/data quality
mechanisms.evidence: The industry could draw up data storage standards, possibly developed by the Association of British Insurers (ABI) or British Standards Institute.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Data discrimination audits are all potential measures to ensure AI and data continue to be used for the public good.

mechanisms.name: Labelling/disclosure requirements
mechanisms.evidence: Insurers could respond to these criticisms by making several adjustments, including by being more upfront with customers about the types of data they use.

mechanisms.name: Complaints/redress mechanism
mechanisms.evidence: It may give the false impression to customers that insurers hold little data on them, which in turn prevents them from exercising their right to challenge the use of that data.

inventory.summary: The policy document explores the ethical implications of AI in personal insurance, focusing on privacy, fairness, and transparency. It proposes mechanisms like data governance standards and algorithmic audits to ensure AI is used responsibly, emphasizing the need for transparency and public engagement to build trust and ensure equitable outcomes.
