inventory.summary: The European Lighthouse for Secure and Safe AI policy emphasizes the development of AI systems that are trustworthy, safe, and aligned with European values. It explicitly endorses values such as trust, safety, privacy, diversity, non-discrimination, fairness, well-being, and sustainability. principles.evidence: Questions regarding the ethical responsibility for the decisions taken will be complicated.

principles.evidence: Development and application of new technology must not be in the hands of homogeneous groups but should reflect diversity and gender equality.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop

principles.name: Purpose limitation

inventory.summary: The policy document focuses on integrating AI systems into public sector auditing to enhance efficiency and support anticorruption efforts. It emphasizes the importance of transparency, accountability, and human oversight in AI deployment, while also proposing capacity building for auditors to maximize the benefits of AI technologies.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building

inventory.summary: The policy document outlines the structure and access protocols for advanced computing resources in Portugal, focusing on collaboration and capacity building. It does not explicitly address ethical values or principles but emphasizes partnerships and training to support the national HPC ecosystem.

inventory.summary: The Declaration of U.S.-UK Cooperation in AI R&D emphasizes the importance of AI for economic growth, health, and democratic values, while promoting trust and international collaboration. title: CDEI Snapshot Paper: Deepfakes and Audio-visual Disinformation

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: The distress caused by non-consensual deepfake pornography highlights privacy concerns.

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: Even rudimentary deepfakes can cause harm.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Deepfakes could undermine our political discourse and trust in media.

values.name: Freedom/liberty
values.evidence: Legislation could stifle free speech under the guise of tackling disinformation.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: We need a robust system of governance to ensure fabricated content is identified, contained and removed before it can inflict damage.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Social media platforms could offer guidance on how to sense-check videos and images.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: The new Online Harms White Paper sets out a proposal to establish a new duty of care that would hold tech companies to account.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: The government, tech companies and media forensics specialists must continue exploring and piloting new containment measures.

principles.name: Precaution/risk-based approach
principles.evidence: We therefore need a robust system of governance to ensure fabricated content is identified, contained and removed before it can inflict damage.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Journalists in particular could benefit from screening aids as they attempt to discern fact from fiction.

mechanisms.name: Legislation
mechanisms.evidence: Legislators around the world are considering new laws to suppress audio and visual disinformation.

mechanisms.name: Detection
mechanisms.evidence: Detection is another important containment tool.

mechanisms.name: Education
mechanisms.evidence: A third means of managing deepfakes is through public education.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: The government, tech companies and media forensics specialists must continue exploring and piloting new containment measures.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Tech companies may also wish to exchange best practice methods and tools for spotting deepfakes.

inventory.summary: The policy addresses the ethical challenges posed by deepfakes and audiovisual disinformation, emphasizing the need for a robust governance system. It highlights the importance of balancing regulation with the protection of free speech and the promotion of beneficial uses of technology. The policy suggests legislative, detection, and educational measures to manage the risks associated with deepfakes.

title: AI Ecosystem Survey “Summary Report: Informing The National AI Strategy"

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: 77% of respondents agreed that increased regulation of AI was a priority in order to improve and maintain public trust.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The survey sought to gather the views of the AI ecosystem to inform the Office for AI’s development of its upcoming National AI Strategy.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Some respondents also flagged that technical and non-technical AI safety was the top issue to safeguard critical infrastructure.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Respondents suggested training aimed at business leaders and management as a valuable solution to equipping decision makers with the necessary technical insight.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Providing appropriate access to, and privacy constraints for, health data across the lifecycle.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: 77% of respondents agreed there were immediate steps that most organisations in their sector/domain could take to build trust and transparency in the use of AI.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Issues of liability, accountability, explainability and robustness of AI systems were also raised.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Ensuring access for underrepresented groups would help to widen the talent pool.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: The overwhelming majority of respondents (88%) agreed that the UK should seek to lead the development of data governance on AI.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: Many respondents said that the UK needs to work with international partners, such as the EU, to develop good data and AI practices.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Respondents mentioned offering more upskilling in AI, embedding training in higher education courses and funding AI apprenticeships more widely.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Some respondents stated that standards in trustworthy AI are currently not well defined.

mechanisms.name: Regulatory sandbox
mechanisms.evidence: Light-touch regulation, developed in tandem with companies that develop AI, would be the best approach to regulating new uses of AI.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: The UK Government could play a role in addressing this through open access to datasets that are assured Government data.

The document suggests mechanisms like training, standards, and open data to enhance AI governance and public trust.

The OECD AI Principles are referenced as a standard for trustworthy AI.

The policy document provides a brief overview of various initiatives and programs related to digital transformation, telecommunications, digital inclusion, human development, industry development, innovation, and artificial intelligence in Egypt. However, it lacks explicit mention of ethical values, principles, or specific governance mechanisms related to AI ethics and governance. The document primarily outlines organizational and strategic components without detailing ethical considerations.

title: Resolution on AI: Questions of Interpretation and Application of International Law

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: Notes the lasting deterioration in the Union’s security environment in the face of multiple challenges directly or indirectly affecting the security of its Member States and citizens: armed conflicts and fragile states... provoking massive population displacement and human rights abuses.

values.name: Peace
values.evidence: Stresses that these challenges are best met together, not by any single country; considers it vital for the EU to respond to these challenges rapidly, consistently and effectively, with one voice and in concert with allies, partners and other international organisations.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Notes the lasting deterioration in the Union’s security environment in the face of multiple challenges directly or indirectly affecting the security of its Member States and citizens.

values.name: Solidarity
values.evidence: Welcomes the recognition of shared security interests and the growing political will on the part of European Union’s Member States... to act collectively for their security.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Considers that instability and unpredictability on the Union’s borders and in its immediate neighbourhood... pose both a direct and indirect threat to the security of the continent; stresses the inextricable link between internal and external security.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: Stresses that these challenges are best met together, not by any single country; considers it vital for the EU to respond to these challenges rapidly, consistently and effectively, with one voice and in concert with allies, partners and other international organisations.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: Calls on the Member States to carry out a solid annual review that helps to take stock of progress in implementing the civilian CSDP compact and that is able to support the further professionalisation of civilian CSDP missions beyond 2023, including measures to ensure the accountability of all actors involved for the missions’ achievements.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: Considers that European strategic autonomy is based on the ability of the Union to strengthen its freedom to assess its independent operational capacity, comprising credible military forces, its industrial capacity to produce the equipment that its forces need and its political capacity to take decisions where circumstances so require.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Reiterates its support for Taiwan’s meaningful participation in international organisations, mechanisms and activities.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Stresses the need to assess missions and operations on a regular basis in order to make them more effective.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Calls on the Member States to carry out a solid annual review that helps to take stock of progress in implementing the civilian CSDP compact.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Welcomes, therefore, the Council’s decision of July 2018 to extend the mandate of the European Union Training Mission in Central African Republic (EUTM RCA) by two years and its intention to launch a civilian mission to complement the military component.

principles.evidence: DigitalLead bygger bro mellem virksomheder, iværksættere og vidensinstitutioner.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: DigitalLead tilbyder nu i samarbejde med Teknologisk Institut en skræddersyet stresstest.

mechanisms.name: Networking events
mechanisms.evidence: By pairing targeted networking and market insights at the HPC Summit in Stockholm.

inventory.summary: The DigitalLead policy emphasizes innovation and collaboration through multi-stakeholder partnerships to enhance digital business development in Denmark. It provides accessible knowledge and networking opportunities to foster public interest and common good. The policy includes mechanisms like training and capacity building to strengthen digital resilience.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The chatbot is part of a unified hub that brings together many public services, forms, and government interactions.

values.name: Accessibility
values.evidence: It was developed to make government services more accessible and efficient by providing immediate, AI-powered support for citizens.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: The chatbot is available 24/7 and supports both Maltese and English.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Integrated with options for live agent interaction when the chatbot cannot address a query.

inventory.summary: The AI chatbot policy in Malta focuses on enhancing accessibility and efficiency of public services through a 24/7 multilingual chatbot. It implicitly supports public interest by integrating human oversight for queries beyond the chatbot's capabilities.

values.name: Sustainability/environment
values.evidence: Facilitate communication and cooperation for sustainable agriculture, forestry and rural areas.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: Engage local actors in the design and delivery of strategies for the development of their rural areas.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: Encourage further networking among participants and promote stakeholder engagement.

principles.name: Knowledge exchange
principles.evidence: Facilitate communication and cooperation between those with a keen interest in sharing knowledge and innovative ideas.

mechanisms.name: Capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Capacity-building event on assessing digitalisation under CAP Strategic Plans.

mechanisms.name: Networking & evaluation
mechanisms.evidence: The European Evaluation Helpdesk for the CAP provides tailored support to EU Member States.

mechanisms.name: Local development method
mechanisms.evidence: LEADER is a local development method used for 30 years to engage local actors.

inventory.summary: The policy emphasizes sustainability and the public interest by promoting inclusiveness and knowledge exchange. It establishes mechanisms for capacity building, networking, and local development to support sustainable agriculture and rural development.

values.name: Equality, diversity and inclusion
values.evidence: improving equality, diversity and inclusion (EDI) is a no-regret investment for the state

values.name: Innovation
values.evidence: stimulate innovation and entrepreneurship in quantum technologies

values.name: Collaboration
values.evidence: greater national and international collaboration in the field of quantum technologies

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: build awareness of quantum technologies and real-world benefits across a broad range of stakeholders

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: contributing to, and learning from, international best practice

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: developing a pipeline of agile, innovative and highly skilled individuals

mechanisms.name: Collaboration frameworks
mechanisms.evidence: strengthen collaborative work between academia and enterprise

inventory.summary: The Quantum 2030 policy for Ireland emphasizes the importance of equality, diversity, and inclusion, alongside fostering innovation and collaboration in quantum technologies. It proposes mechanisms for training and international cooperation to build a quantum-literate society and stimulate economic competitiveness through enhanced research and entrepreneurship.

title: Digital Wallonia Strategy on Digital Administration

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: The ambition to develop a new model of public services for Wallonia as a platform suggests a focus on the common good.

values.name: Openness
values.evidence: The policy mentions 'ouverture et l’activation des données publiques' which translates to the opening and activation of public data.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: The aim to offer an integrated experience to citizens and businesses across various channels implies inclusiveness.

principles.name: Open source/openness
principles.evidence: The policy explicitly mentions 'ouverture et l’activation des données publiques'.

mechanisms.name: Data sharing/open data
mechanisms.evidence: The policy proposes the 'ouverture et l’activation des données publiques' to enable collaboration.

mechanisms.name: Experimental deployment
mechanisms.evidence: Public services are to serve as a 'terrain d’expérimentation et de déploiement' for innovative digital solutions.

inventory.summary: The Digital Wallonia Strategy on Digital Administration aims to transform Wallonia into a platform-based region by adopting digital service models similar to major digital platforms. It emphasizes openness and data sharing to foster collaboration among administrations, citizens, and businesses, and proposes using public services as a testing ground for innovative digital solutions.

inventory.summary: The Armenia Digital Agenda – 2030 focuses on promoting digital transformation across various sectors, emphasizing accessibility and inclusiveness by extending technology access beyond urban centers. It implicitly values public interest and equality, proposing mechanisms like stakeholder engagement and a roadmap to guide implementation.

inventory.summary: The AI Programmer Vocational Education policy in Bulgaria focuses on integrating AI skills into high school curricula to address the national AI skills gap. It emphasizes sustainability, public interest, and well-being by preparing students for the digital economy and creating inclusive educational opportunities. The policy establishes mechanisms for certification and practical training to build capacity in AI programming.

values.name: Privacy/Data Protection
values.evidence: This website uses cookies to improve your experience while you navigate through the website.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: We use cookies on our website to give you the most relevant experience by remembering your preferences and repeat visits.

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: Necessary cookies are absolutely essential for the website to function properly. These cookies ensure basic functionalities and security features of the website, anonymously.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: The cookie is set by GDPR Cookie Consent plugin and is used to store whether or not user has consented to the use of cookies.

principles.name: Informed Consent
principles.evidence: By clicking 'Accept All', you consent to the use of ALL the cookies.

mechanisms.name: Consent Management
mechanisms.evidence: You may visit 'Cookie Settings' to provide a controlled consent.

inventory.summary: The AI4T policy emphasizes privacy and data protection through explicit consent mechanisms for cookie usage. It implicitly supports trust and security by ensuring essential functionalities and security features. Transparency and informed consent are operational principles, with established mechanisms for managing user consent.

inventory.summary: Latvia's National AI Strategy emphasizes the protection of human rights, fairness, privacy, safety, and trust in AI technologies. values.name: Efficiency

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: Displays information from trades processed through Comprasnet in a dashboard.

principles.evidence: SOFIA is a virtual assistant that checks for errors and suggests changes in the texts of managers and auditors.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility

inventory.summary: The policy document focuses on the integration of AI systems in public sector auditing to enhance efficiency and support anticorruption efforts. It emphasizes the importance of transparency, accountability, and human oversight in the use of AI technologies, while also highlighting the need for training and capacity building to improve auditors' skills. The document implicitly values public interest and efficiency, with mechanisms such as monitoring and evaluation, and recognition awards to promote innovation.

inventory.summary: The policy focuses on the deployment of AI-enabled delivery robots to address urban logistics challenges. It emphasizes safety, efficiency, and collaboration among stakeholders to enhance last-mile delivery systems. The initiative implicitly values public interest and reliability, aiming to integrate autonomous solutions into existing logistics networks.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: The development of formal methods...is therefore vital for increasing the trust in software systems among the general public.

values.name: Safety/Security
values.evidence: INSAIT’s research in computer security aims to protect modern computer systems from malicious interventions.

values.name: Privacy/Data Protection
values.evidence: Modern computer systems...are often deployed in security- and privacy-critical domains.

values.name: Well-being/Beneficence
values.evidence: The impressive increase in the capabilities and availability of conventional computers...has brought enormous benefits to our society.

principles.name: Robustness/Reliability
principles.evidence: How can we ensure that learning-based algorithms are sufficiently robust, fair, and reliable to be used in practice?

principles.name: Explainability/Interpretability
principles.evidence: The development of formal methods...with the goal of developing provably robust, safe, and interpretable software systems.

principles.name: Data Governance/Data Quality
principles.evidence: At INSAIT, we study many fundamental questions regarding data management, including topics related to...privacy, data governance, data erasure and many others.

principles.name: Human Oversight/Human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Reasoning, the ability of humans to consciously draw conclusions...is perhaps the most unique feature of human intelligence.

mechanisms.name: Training/Capacity Building
mechanisms.evidence: At INSAIT, we seek to provide answers to such questions, striving for a thorough theoretical and practical understanding of data-driven algorithms.

mechanisms.name: Standards/Technical Standards
mechanisms.evidence: developing practical and secure communication protocols and systems.

inventory.summary: The INSAIT Research Programmes focus on advancing AI and computer science through robust and reliable methods, emphasizing security, privacy, and trust. The policy implicitly supports ethical values such as well-being and safety, while explicitly addressing principles like robustness and data governance. Mechanisms for capacity building and technical standards are proposed to ensure the practical application of these principles.

title: Ethical Framework for Artificial Intelligence in Colombia

values.name: Human dignity
values.evidence: The policy emphasizes the importance of respecting human dignity in AI development.

values.name: Human rights
values.evidence: AI systems must uphold and respect human rights.

values.name: Fairness/justice/equity
values.evidence: Ensuring fairness and equity in AI applications is a key concern.

values.name: Non-discrimination
values.evidence: The policy calls for AI systems to avoid discrimination.

values.name: Privacy/data protection
values.evidence: Protecting privacy and data is a fundamental requirement.

values.name: Autonomy/self-determination
values.evidence: AI should support human autonomy and self-determination.

values.name: Well-being/beneficence
values.evidence: AI should contribute to human well-being.

values.name: Non-maleficence/do no harm
values.evidence: AI systems should not cause harm.

values.name: Trust
values.evidence: Building trust in AI technologies is essential.

values.name: Safety/security
values.evidence: Ensuring the safety and security of AI systems is a priority.

values.name: Public interest/common good
values.evidence: AI should serve the public interest and common good.

principles.name: Transparency
principles.evidence: AI systems should be transparent in their operations.

principles.name: Explainability/interpretability
principles.evidence: AI decisions should be explainable and interpretable.

principles.name: Accountability
principles.evidence: There should be accountability for AI systems and their outcomes.

principles.name: Responsibility
principles.evidence: Developers and users of AI must take responsibility for their actions.

principles.name: Robustness/reliability
principles.evidence: AI systems must be robust and reliable.

principles.name: Human oversight/human-in-the-loop
principles.evidence: Human oversight is necessary in AI decision-making processes.

principles.name: Inclusiveness/accessibility
principles.evidence: AI should be inclusive and accessible to all.

principles.name: Data governance/data quality
principles.evidence: High standards of data governance and quality are required.

principles.name: International cooperation
principles.evidence: The policy encourages international cooperation in AI governance.

mechanisms.name: Impact assessment
mechanisms.evidence: AI impact assessments are mandatory for evaluating potential effects.

mechanisms.name: Algorithmic auditing/third-party audit
mechanisms.evidence: Third-party audits of AI systems are suggested to ensure compliance.

mechanisms.name: Certification/conformity assessment
mechanisms.evidence: Certification processes for AI systems are recommended.

mechanisms.name: Training/capacity building
mechanisms.evidence: Training programs for AI developers and users are encouraged.

mechanisms.name: Monitoring & evaluation/reporting
mechanisms.evidence: Regular monitoring and reporting on AI systems are required.

mechanisms.name: Standards/technical standards
mechanisms.evidence: Development of technical standards for AI is proposed.

inventory.summary: The Ethical Framework for Artificial Intelligence in Colombia emphasizes the protection of human rights, fairness, and transparency in AI systems. It mandates impact assessments and encourages international cooperation, aiming to ensure AI technologies are developed and used responsibly, safely, and inclusively for the public good.
